Colora√ß√£o vermelho/amarronzada. Creme denso, consistente e persistente. Aroma com predomin√¢ncia de nozes (a Fabi sentiu macad√¢mia), chocolate, cravo e menos de malte torrado.
O sabor acompanha o aroma. Carbonata√ß√£o intensa, mas bem balanceada. √Ålcool evidente, mas bem inserido. Extremamente encorpada. Definitivamente, uma cerveja de personalidade marcante. Uma honra beb√™-la.

Dark red-brown colour with creamy head. Bit sweet aroma  of fruits and caramel. Sweet flavour of dark malts, caramel, fruits. Good mouthfeel though far from the same as in the Carolus Christmas ale.  A great beer.

We had a little begian beer taste test, with this beer going up against St. Bernardus triple and Gouden Christmas Ale. This one was the most popular. Hazy nut brown with a creamy tan head that stuck around until the finish. Rich nutty caramel aroma, faintly fruity. Silky smooth, very rich and malty with sponge toffee and caramel flavours, a little fruitiness, a little breadiness and a spicy finish with a suggestion of licorice. Truly excellent and a pleasure to drink.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle.  Very nice looking beer. Mahogany colour with medium creamy head. Spicy flavor sweet and bitter. Wery well balanced. Full body and nice aftertaste.

Bottle:  Pours brown and mahoghany with a thick, creamy beige head.  Thick lacing.  Nose of fruit and malty, some hints of a caramel like sweetness.  Taste is sweeter with fruitiness, wine, plum, and citrus.  I swear there is a hint of bananas?  Very silky and smooth, crisp right at the end.  No real notice of the higher ABV.  Very good.

Not very strong aroma of chocolate or something like that.
The flavour is well balanced between sweet and bitter notes. 
I can¬ít describe its flavour very well, but I liked it. Very interesting beer. The alcohol is well hiden...
Hop Leaf, Chicago.  I enjoyed this beer quite a bit.  Earthy flavor, maybe even a little smoky?  Very unique.

I think the best thing this one has going for it is the way it looks.  Aside from that  its a lot like some other belgians but not as complex.  the alcohol overpowers this one whereas in others strong beers it compliments the wide variety of flavours you¬íre experiencing.
Have had this at a couple ABVs. An ale I can get here in Alberta and haven¬ít visited enough. Pg 192 of Michael Jackson¬ís Great Beer Guide and only 379 out 500 Classic Brews to go.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2007 Bottle from Uto. Pours a lovely mahogany with orange highlights and a hearty tan head. Words do little justice for the appearance. Aroma of raisins, caramel and plum with an underbelly of yeast and rum. Sweet to spicy taste of toasted malts, caramel and berries. Wonderful full body, this is glorious stuff!
Re-rate - Draught @ Brasserie Het Anker. Deep amber with a creamy malt head that left a great lacing. Aroma of malt, yeast, dark fruits and chocolate. Taste is much the same, slightly sweet but all the other characteristics keep it from going too far. Creamy and smooth on the palate with some alcohol warmth. As the name implies, a classic...

Bright ruby body with a modest frothy beige head.  Warm kettle caramelization, plum, cherry, and toffee aromas.  Flavor is medium sweet with light fruit skin acidity and bitterness.  Cola tones early, but nice dark fruit qualities develop as it warms.  Very solid stuff from Het Anker.

darker than i expected, big off white head, aroma id lots of fruit, especially raisins and plums. flavour is the same, but i¬ím getting alot of booze, as it¬ís warming up he bozeis comming through more and more decent belgian but........nothing spectacular.

[103-20061118] Tap @ Point Brugge (Pittsburgh, PA). Aroma is malted and yeasty, reminds me of sweet beef OXO boullion cubes. Cloudy, brown body with a fair-lasting creamy light brown head and nice lacing on the glass. Some raisin and figgy fruity flavour characteristics along with light celery, hops, and some chewy toffee in this OXO beefed-up beer, and the alcohol is obvious. Medium-full body. Seems exotic, would have preferred a smaller sample.

750ml bottle pours dark copper in color with a creamy light tan head that stays fairly well and laces some.  Aromas of raisins, caramel, candi sugar, and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is full and rich with caramel, raisin, prune, yeast ,some bannana, and some pepperlike spice at the warm finish.  Well carbonated palate with good full body and a somewhat dry finish..

Brown bottle, 33 cl, best before 4.09.09; eye: ruby, nice creamy coffee-color head, clear, light effervescence, nice creamy lacing; nose: alcohol, concentrated caramel syrup, banana, concentrated fruits; mouth: velvety despite the powerful tastes, alcohol, syrupy, caramelized malt, almost hidden banana, hint of grainy hops, finale in alcohol entetwined with caramel and a hint of alcohol that comes back as pepper, full body, creamy and really slighlty grainy texture, lightly astringent, mildly sweet, really light hoppiness, medium carbonation; overall: quite good

FRAN√áAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, meilleure avant 04.09.09; oeil : rubis, belle mousse cr√©meuse, claire, l√©g√®re effervescence, belle dentelle cr√©meuse; nez : alcool, sirop caram√©lis√© concentr√©, banane, fruits concentr√©s; bouche : velout√© malgr√© des saveurs puissantes, alcool, sirupeux, malt caram√©lis√©, pr√©sence subtile de banane, l√©ger houblon granuleux, finale en alcool entrem√™l√©e de caramel avec une touche d¬íalcool qui revient sous forme poivre, cors√©e, texture cr√©meuse et tr√®s l√©g√®rement granuleuse, l√©g√®re astringence, moyennement sucr√©e, tr√®s l√©ger houblon, carbonatation moyenne; en r√©sum√© : pas mal bon

330ml bottle.  Hazy brown hue with defined ruby highlights.  Thick, creamy off-white head.  Sweet smokey nose.  Strong caramel and toffee aromas.  Hints of cooked sugar and cinnamon spices.  Apparent alcohol nose.  Full bodied with a smooth malty sweetness.  Toffee notes with a warming alcohol note.  Burnt sugar sweetness.  Cocoa.  Slight citrus lemony yeast note.  Long and sticky, but on a lighter note.  These guys make fantastic beers!

On tap at Hopleaf.  A murky brown with a beige head.  Aromas of raisins and chocolate.  The taste had some figs,  raisins, moderately sweet.  A nut like smoked wood on the palate.  A very nice Belgian.

Bottle: Pours deep amber with a medium sized beige, fluffy head. Some lacing is present. Yeast, malt, caramel and dark fruit in the nose. Sweet flavour of dark fruit, mild chocolate and carmel. Creamy texture. Medium to full bodied. Malt, brown sugar and a little alcohol in the finish. A very nice brew.
Overall, this beer is generally sweet. Enjoyable aroma, with solid flavor - with an emphasis on sweet. palate is average, but the beer is good.
0.33l bottle. Dark reddish-brown with beige head. Medium lacing. Aroma of fruit, caramel and yeast. Thick, smooth mouthful. Taste is sweet, spicy and yeasty. Very good Belgian ale.

On tap at Delirium Caf√©, G√∂teborg, Sweden. Dark brown with a copper tone, nice fruity aroma. In the mouth, along a nice smooth feeling,  a wonderful flavor evolves, complex malts, a touch of wood, chocolate,  and with no alcohol coming through. Excellent.
Bottle 33 cl. Aroma: caramel and slightly alcohol. Brown colour, small, light brown, head. Caramel flavour with some spiciness. Medium-body. Taste is sweet-bitter.
This has a very rich flavor and aroma, I don¬ít know much about belgium beers or beers in general but this is one of the best beers I have ever tasted
Bottle purchased at Whole Foods NYC: pours a nice dark reddish brown, strong aroma of raisins and figs, kind of a burnt caramel taste.  A nice Belgian.
Bottle. Chestnut brown color, rich brown head. Dark fruits, yeast, some chocolate. Nice beer.

0.75 l bottle. Reddish brown color with creamy tan head. Malty and fruity aroma with raisins, figs, chocolade, almonds and rum. Sweet flavor with tart fruitiness and rum. Long, tart, sweet and warming finish with notes of licorice.

Pours deep mahogany into a trappist glass.  Micro head stays steady on the surface.  Plum, pear, cabernet and alcohol aromas. Creamy with upfront prune and raisin and a lasting caramel cherry flambe finish.

Bottle in a mixed pack for Christmas. Pours dark brown with a large creamy head, some dried fruits on the nose with  wafts of alcohol and sweetness. Taste is gloriously smooth with dried fruits and a continuing molasses sweetness and quite sticky. I will add that as much as I liked this it didn¬ít quite measure up to being as good as the sum of it¬ís parts had promised. Still a very good beer.
Nice amber color with a big tan head.  Aromas of yeast and wheat.  Nutmeg and hop flavors.  Slight caramel tastes as well.  Very interesting and good belgian beer.

Bottle. Average creamy off-white head that was mostly lasting. Good lacing left in glass. Murky body with particulate and a dark brown colour. Heavy malt with notes of molasses, caramel, chocolate, roasted, nutty. Light citrus and some cheese, banana, plum and date. Slight port feel with light notes of wood being present. Full bodied with a flat carbonation and a creamy like texture. Moderated to heavy sweet flavour with some notes of bitterness to it. Finish is short to average with sweetness as the bearing flavour. Reminded me of the Gouden Carolus Cuvee Van De Keizer in a lighter version. Very nice!
Bottled. Deep brown, chessnut coloured body with a fine, beige head. Sweet, floral aroma, generous and uplifting. Well round flavour on the palate, silky...really silky. Liked it.
Dark amber with a small, but staying head. Aroma has lots of sweet fruits - some plums. Some sherry-like tones as well. Lightly vinious. Taste has lots of caramel and dried fruits.

Pours a nice semi dark hazy brown with a medium layer of froathy offwhite head.  Aroma is brown sugar, oak, raisins, and spices.  Absolutely delicious.  Flavor is sweet, brown sugar, and slightly burbony.  Overall, very very enjoyable.

Bottle, strong sweet malt aroma with hints of dried fruit.  Good bubbly head with cola dark reddish brown color, semi- transparent.  Flavor is sweet balanced with a light dryness.  Woody, raisny, strong malt flavor.  Seems like it will be too dry but then balances out well on the finish.  Good carbonation.  Very drinkable.  Very good overall.

Intense bubblegum aroma that mixes well with rich malty, bready notes. Flavor is bubblegum, caramel, and some bread and dark fruit. Mouthfeel is nearly syrupy, but not unpleasant. Huge flavors and aromas with no significant detractors.

Bottle.Dark brown with a offwhite froth. Licorice, spices, caramel aroma. Delicious and balanced licorice caramel flavours, semidry throughout. Good mouthfeel, full body. A Belgian classic that never disappoints.

I will definitely have to give this another go. I wanted to give it higher reviews but in the end I didn¬ít feel it was justified. A cloudy light brown color with an aroma of caramelized sugar and malts. Flavors were sweet with caramel, molasses and brown sugar. Finish was a little harsh. Good, but I will see if these ratings hold up with another bottle.
Aroma of chocolate cake, toffee and liqurice. Hazy red/brown colour with a thick head. Very sweet and fulfilling taste, long finish which is both sweet and bitter. Excellent!

Deep brown color with amber and slightly purple highlights.  Thick, sticky tan head of tiny microbubbles.  Delicious aroma of dark brown sugar, dried fruits (dates, raisins), sweet malts, caramel, licorice, and some faint spiciness.  Equally delicious, intense, somewhat acidic flavors of dried fruits (dates, raisins, apples), dark caramelized sugars, spices (coriander, nutmeg, anise), cocoa, toffee, and a slight hint of warming alcohol, and a nearly imperceptible amount of hops.  Smooth, rich body with a touch of prickly carbonation on the tongue.  Nicely sticky and velvety, but not overbearing--finishes crisp and clean, a bit dry from the hops.  An amazing beer.
pours nicely with a lovely head, but this soon dissipates. A lovely initial smell and tart taste that only improves with age....gorgeous

Bottled(330ml). ¬ñDeep reddish/brown coloured, medium sized beige head. Aroma is malty, fruity (raisins, cherries, orange) and spicy with notes of toffee, chocolate and obvious alcohol presence with just a tiny coriander hint. Pleasant spicy finish.

Bottle. Poured a dark amber brown with a medium white head with medium lacing. Chocolate, caramel and dark fruit aroma. Taste can only be described as wonderful. Very sweet taste comprised of dark fruit, chocolate and carmel. There was a little alcohol taste but not harsh. It was slightly stick on lips but still had some carbonation on the tongue. Not quite as good as their grand cru, which is probably my favorite beer, but has instanly become one of my favorites.

The 11.2 ounce bottle poured a hazy dark mahogany brown colored beverage with a small off-white head that was mostly diminishing but left some lacing on the glass. The aroma was highly complex mix of fruits and spices with notes of dark berries, dates, raisins, banana, pepper and coriander. The body was medium-full with normal carbonation and a smooth slightly dry texture. The flavor starts off sweet but not overly sweet and stays that way through the medium-long finish. The sweet taste is composed of many of the flavors that the aroma displays. Very nice.

750ml bottle picked up at Alko in Tampere and sampled at a drinking party in Troms√∏. Inviting dark brown red-tinged body with great clarity and a fading off-white foam. Port-like profile. Spicy to the nose. Taste of sweet, dark berries with a yeasty touch towards the end. Almost full bodied. Decent brew, but too much candy sweetness to get a higher score (18.11.2006).
Bottle 0,75l. Dark red brown coloured. A disappearing off-white head. Very sweet all the way: Some spice in the nose. Hints of prunes in the aftertaste. Alcohol well hidden.

Drank in a stem glass.  Small long lasting dark amber head.  Dark copper body.  Aromas of blackberries, plums while getting warmer there were aromas of dates, raisins and a hint of wine yieast.  Caramel, bananas and old wine barrels completed the aromas of this amazing beer.  Light bitterness and a creamy alcohol finish.  Flavors of caramel, honey and Mcintosh apple puree.  The aromas of wine was very well transfered to the flavors.  Extremely well balanced beer.

Reddish brown with a lasting, light, tan coloured head. Aroma of sweet, dried fruits and fortified vine, and just a hint of quite christmassy spices.
Quite pleasing and warming taste of chocolate (not the bitter kind mind you), raisins, vanilla and maybe some cherries or blackberries - can¬ít quite decide.
Not the most exciting beer ever but definetely well breved and very pleasant.
raisin, date, caramel aroma.  cloudy brown with a small yellowish head.  toffee, caramel, raisin flavored with hints of chocolate.  medium bodied.

Hazy brick red with a thin solid head. Very vinous and tart aroma, funky with fruit and toasted bread notes. The flavor is like flowers infused in fruit juice. It is a bit on the hot side though. Finishes clean, tart and quenching. Excellent.

Concentrated notes of sweet plums and raisins waft from my glass as I pour this beer, there is also a touch of something like rum.  The beer is quite well carbonated and produces a frothy, easily three-finger thick, tan colored head even after carefully pouring this into my tulip glass.  The beer is a hazy, dark amber color that has deep purple overtones.  An interesting aroma is on this one; it certainly smells rich and decadent.  Notes of concentrated, caramelized brown sugar lead to something akin to cinnamon (though not quite) and some definite prune like notes.  Woody fig notes lend a sort of dryness here, but the more you delve into the aroma the more concentrated and varied the rich concentrated fruit notes get.  The concentrated fruit character never takes on a sharp, exaggerated fruitiness, but instead remains rounded by the caramelized malt core that makes up this beer.

Definitely sweet, this beer has a heft to it that sticks to the palate and in fact coats it as the beer passes through my mouth.  It finishes with a certain chalkiness that makes me think that this might have started to oxidize.  It has not reached the point of cardboard, but it may have started down that path.  Perhaps cardboard is not the best descriptor as this beer still has ample room to move towards much more pleasing notes of sherry, which I definitely get hints of already.  Rum like notes of brown sugar and molasses linger on the tongue as a touch of alcohol warms my chest.  This has lots of concentrated, caramelized malt flavors.  It is almost has a toffee like edge to it, but with only a touch of the butter character.

This is quite the sipping brew, each sip is rich and complex enough to be contemplative, and it is certainly thick enough that quaffing large draughts of this at a time would not be pleasant.  It is right on the edge of being too sweet; it has achieved a great amount of richness without being overly sweet, but just so as any more would be sticky and cloying.  In the end I think this is a touch too sweet, it has certainly been an enjoyable way to end the evening though.

Purchased: Plaza Liquors, Tucson AZ
Bottle (BB Apr 2009). Fruity and toffeish a little spice. Sweet and creamy. Not too my taste and slightly one dimensional but not unpleasant.
Bottle. Dark brownish colour with a huge mostly lasting creamy head. Aroma and taste of malts and fruits. Good beer. Slightly alcoholic finish.

Bottle, 1 pint 9.4 oz.  Great pour with decent head.  Simmers down as sweet aroma arises.  Fruit tastes as berries and twigs, slight nuts... well rounded.  Alcohol not too apparent.  Finishes smooth.  Lulls one to great times.

(Bottle BB 14/06/09) Caramel and slightly alcohol aroma. Amber colour, bright and small, light brown, fully diminishing head. Caramel and berry-like  flavour with slight spiciness. Lively carbonated, alcoholic (not too much; actually only warming), medium-bodied and slightly syrupy palate. Very delicious strong ale! 10/09/06

Dark brown color with a small  white head. Malty with notes of fruit (citrus ?)
Medium to full body with a long and very complex, bitter/sweet aftertaste.

rootbeer brown body with small white head...splendid aroma of chewy malts, toasty caramels, toffee, nougat, twigs and berries...flavor begins nice and sugary, leading to caramel, brown sugar, and molasses notes...nice palate, and an excellent beer!

Bottle is from BeerBuzzMontreal and has been cellaring for at least a year and a half. bb 14/06/06. Served in a NB worthy glass.  Color is orange/reddish brown with a small kahki head. The aroma is kahlua (first time I have ever said that) with some sour cherries and vanilla in the background. Beer is still quite cool, another 10¬∞F  should bring the aromas out, still very good smelling. As it warms dark fruits emerge. The intial mouthfeel is huge. The intial taste is nutty, deep dark fruits, vanilla, yeast, and wood followed by a bit of alcohol and tanginess. The flavor is missing a little complexity (for the style) but this doesn¬ít diminish the fact that this is a great beer. Thanks BBM!
Bottle. Nice brown beer with notes of sweetness, fruit, yeast and well balanced. Sweet finish!
On Tap at Flying Pie Boise. Pours out a Dark brown topped with a small tan head. Very smooth for a Belgain strong.

12 oz bottle.dark brown with small tan lacing. nose is very sweet-sugary malt, raisin, date, spices, alcohol. flavor is similar to nose with a hot alcohol burn that does not take over the palate by any means but shows its presence. a very nice belgian strong.
On tap. Dark brown with cream colored head. Aroma is caramel, molasses, raisin. Flavor is the same and slightly spicy. Nice sweetness without being overpowering.

Tasted late at night during the World Cup at the Delirium caf√©, Brussels whilst the music thumped and the swaggering Italian horde around me cheered and ol√©¬íed their teams latest victory. Into it¬ís own chalice from the bottle. Slight haze shadowed the lights beaming through it¬ís deep tawny copper body. Head was magnificently rocky, tannish, an inch thick and steadfast, lacing intricately down the glass as it went.  From there on the notes got vague so I¬íll rely on memory!?!
Huge malty aroma, bursting with savoury fruits, dusty hops, blended spices and rich liqueur. Big and aggressive start in the mouth. Spiced up and flowing with complex malts, burnt and savoury fruits and light little flushes of dessert wine in the back. Alcohol is well masked but does add into giving it a nice long, malty and warming swallow. Light prickle of carbonation before it settles in smooth across the palate. Quite nice overall. Wished I had of taken more notes. Another classic from Het Anker. One to try again. (33cL, BB 12/12/06)

Bottle. Dark copper body topped with a decent beige foamy head. Sharp malty/hoppy aroma with yeasty and plummy notes. Alcohol is very well hidden. Taste is complex and perfectly balanced. Here again, alcohol is barely noticeable. Ends with a good warming and yeasty aftertaste. Superb!

Pour is a deep dark brown with a smallish tan head,  Arom is full of brown sugar, molasses and alcohol.  Flavor is much of the same but even better.  Toffee,dark fruits sugar and nutmeg all come to mind.  Alcohol is there at the end but does not overpower.

Clear amber color with tan head and excellent lacing. Sugary aroma with a hint of beat sugar. Also a nice molasses and toffee smell. Flavor is cherries, dates, cinnamon, sweet toffee malts, maybe coriander and a hint of candi sugar. I also sense a little of the alcohol. Nice melded flavor brew. Enjoyable.

Bottle from Super Saver.  Hazy deep brown/ruby pour with minimal tan head.  Aroma of big banana nut bread at first, with caramel, brown sugar, vinous notes, and figs after sniffing for a while.  The flavor is caramelly, slight burnt toasty malty, with some toffee, brown sugar, vinous fruit, banana, and almond hints.  Very complex palate and fklavor profile which gets a tad tarter and fruitier as it warms.  This one is outstanding.
No head at all, an older sample from Stuffed Sandwich. truly a beer that ages gracefully! Sweetness, malty, but really tastes more like a Red wine, dark red fruits, plain and simple. Delicious!

Bottle. Clear deep brown color with thin beige head. Anis, grapefruits, alcohol and caramel aroma. Taste of caramel, toffee, alcohol, corn syrup. A nice sweetness in the flavor is followed by hops, spices and some alcohol.
Bottle at Delirium. Brown, full head. Malt dominated and very rich. Very unlike other belgian strongs and I like it.
Bottle. Off-white lasting head. Clear ruby body. Dry malt aroma of plums and caramel. Very sweet caramel and brown sugar falvor.

Olney Beer & Fine Wine tasting.  Nice fluffy head, medium bubbles, good retention.  Bready, malty nose.  Malt over-the-top in the mouth, overly sweet - simply too much.  Unbalanced.  Raisins and honey in the finish.

Pours deep red with a two-finger off-white head. Sweet aroma of dark fruit, brown sugar, and a good bit of yeast. Brown sugar and raisin flavor, with a faint complexity of malt flavors--chocolate, toffee, caramel--and some other fruits playing second fiddle. Some sharp yeastiness. Dry finish that turns sweet and smoky a couple seconds after the swallow and sticks around for quite a while. Not bad.

The aroma has raisins, brown sugar, yeast (basement aromas), and malt. The appearance is hazy brown with a red tint. The flavor is much like the aroma and adds some bitterness and warming alcohol. The palate is average. This beer is nice.

33 cl bottle. Red brownish with a medium beige head. Aroma is spicy, with notes of yeast, dark fruits and candy. The taste is pretty much the same, with notes of coffee, toffee and chocolate. Full body. Great beer!

As its name supposes the Carolus Classic is indeed a true archetype of the dark Belgian ales. Its mesmerizing lateritious hue is subtly clouded and rises to an oat-colored creamy head, exemplary of the style. An overwhelming fragrance of bananas emerges initially and follows in a suite of dried pears, raisins and figs. The warm, vinous touch offers a definite density to the nose, one supported by the indubitable scent of walnuts, pepper and the candy-like aroma of artificial cherries. Fruits are equally pronounced in the flavor, particularly in the recurrent vehemence of dried bananas, followed by plums and cherries again. The sweet, sticky almost syrupy texture contributes a certain weight to the dark malt background of coffee, roasted chocolate and caramel weaving an immaculate framework for the assertive nutmeg and anise tonalities. Alcohol is certainly present but does not burn, and for a turophile like myself gives the apropos strength to perfectly match a Chabichou or a similarly soft goat cheese. The aftertaste leads to a beautiful evolution starting with coffee and marrons glac√©s that finishes with the lingering piquant of licorice.
On tap. Light red brownish in colour with a large white head. A bit mild. Sweet and malty with notes of raisins and caramel.

My 900th review and not a bad one. Poured a red-brown color with a nice pillowy tan head in the tulip glass. The lacing was great on the way down, a combination of rings and spotty foam. Aroma was super rich from the pop of the cap, rich dark fruits permeating the air with lots of strength and a touch of caramel. Delicious smelling. Flavor wasn¬ít as good (hey, it¬ís got lots of competition within style), but decent. Flavor gets credit for complexity, anyway: dark fruits, (raisins and plums), caramel, molasses, and light chocolate underneath. A bit sharp in the flavor, maybe even slightly astringent and vinous. Put this one away for years and it would probably improve much. But, for now, it¬ís nothing like the Kaizer, and, well... the flavor of the Noel was much better.
From bottle.  Pours a reddish brown with fluffy tan head.  Nose has hints of dark fruits and a yeasty spiciness.  Flavor follows with a smooth body.  A very well blended BSA.
tap. pours red. has big white head. fruity aroma. rum and spices. sweet and a bit alcoholic. not the best of its kind in my taste.

Bottle.  Clear deep brown color with thin beige head.  Anis, grapefruits, alcohol and caramel aroma.  Taste of caramel, toffee, alcohol, corn syrup and good palate.  

Bi√®re de couleur brune clair mais opaque et un mince collet beige.  Odeur d¬íanis, pamplemousse, alcool et caramel.  Go√ªt de caramel, toffee, alcool et sirop de maiis.  Elle est longue en bouche mais elle tombe un peu sur le coeur.
Taste of grape, cherry, toffee. Very fruity, a few bitterness and the alcohol taste is not too present. But that¬ís not really my favorite kind of beer although.

Great beer! Poures a dark brown beer with a biege head. Aromas of fruits, raisins, woody, rum and  spices. Flavours are of sweet rum, raisin, lighter(berries) and darker fruits(plums), chocolate, sweet and a bit bitter. Heavy body, chewy beer, which reminded me of the high-gravity trappist beers. Excellent and complex!!!

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2012 Bottled, 33cl. Reddish-brown beer, with a beige head and some floaties. It has a rich aroma of toffee, fruits and beef-stock. Some yeastiness too. A nice candi-sweetness in the flavor is followed by hops, spices and some alcohol. It has a light sourness in the finish, and an almost full body. A nice beer, that worked well with sausages and mustard. Rating: 8-4-8-4-16-4.0. 060428Bottle, 33cl. It pours a more or less clear body, dark amber in color, and with a dense, off-white head leaving lacings. There¬ís some oxidation in the aroma, with caramel, sugary sweetness and some dried fruits. The flavor has a decent bitterness, both initially and in the end, and with caramel, white sugar and dried fruits. Some oxidation. Full-bodied, and quite carbonated. A pleasant beer indeed, but either the age of the bottle, which is unknown, or my evolved palate, made me lower my score quite a bit. Maybe I should try a fresh bottle soon. 120106
Bottle. Red brown colour with a white head.Aroma is fruity apple, toffee and yeast. Flavour is weak roasted applewith notes of alcohol and alcohol. Pleasent finish.

Rubin-red to brown colour, with an average off white head. Sweet malty aroma, some yeasty touches, chocolate, little alcoholic. Full body, very nice palate. Finish is little bitter, ending somewhat chocolate- sweeter with some light alcoholic touches. Well balanced, very nice beer.

R√∏d-brun √∏l f√•et som fad p√• Den Tatoverede Enke. 

Er for st√¶rk og krydret i smagen - er sv√¶r at drikke.

(f√•et som nr 7, s√• rating er usikker)

(04.01.06) 330 mL brown bottle purchased at The Tree pub, Beijing, China. ABV 8.5 %.  Bottle states that best before 250408.   Poured clear deep reddish amber  with small white head. Soft carbonation. Spicy fruit in the nose. Medium-to-full bodied Belgium ale that starts with light malt sweetness and caramel/raisin flavors. Finishes with light malt fade.  Alcohol well hidden behind flavors. Definite alcoholic warmth. No funky medicinal phenols or sourness. Smooth and rich tasting with pleasant aroma.  A delicious malty Belgium ale.
Hazy brown in colour. Minor white head. The aroma is fruity and plummy. The fllavour is tasty, very plummy...

YEHAA 400 :-D Pours a dark red amber with an off-white dimminishing head. Moderate sweetness with some bitterness. Aromas of caramel, fruits, yeast (light) and port. Full creamy body with a soft caarbonation. Slightly bitter finish with some alchohol notes.
A very nice medium brown. The 8% alcohol is not noticeable at all. One of the more easily drinkable good Belgians I¬íve had.

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2007 A little better than I expected.  Powerful aroma with mostly fruit, light spice, and sweet malt.  This doesn¬ít have the weird sweetness of Abbaye des Rocs, but is well balanced all around with the sweet fruit flavors.  It looks good with an off white head but no visible sediment.  Overall this is a very high quality Belgian ale that is exactly what I expect of this style.  It is very good all around without excelling in any area.  Rerate March 2007, in Belgium.  Score unchanged.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm) Colour is brown, with hints of dark amber and ruby. Nose is roasted with coffe, some tobacco and dark fruit. Taste is roasted and fruity with hints of dried fruit (figs, raisins) and coffee. Complex and very well balanced.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2007 Brown red colour. Medium carbonation. A lot of fruits like raisins, plums, prunes & cherry. Almost overpowering or harsh. It has a good body and long finish, but personally this is the least good Het Anker brew that I¬íve tasted! Still worth checking out!
Robe rubis tr√®s claire surmont√©e d¬íune mousse beige mince. Ar√¥mes de cersies, d¬í√©pices, d¬íalcool, de malt et de bonbon. Saveurs de bonbon, de cerise, de levure et d¬í√©pices.
Bottled. Cloudy ruby colour with offwhite mediumsized head. Plum, sweet caramel in aroma. Flavour is plummy, fruity and a bit wheaty. Also raisins in the flavour. Sweet sugary aftertaste.

2002 bottle from Bottleworks. Nice dark red color with medium head. Incredible malty aroma, lots of caramel & banana. Very tasty beer....deep, deep malt taste. Tastes of maple syrup and some slight hops coming through. Very carbonated with a thick texture. Leaves an impression on your tongue for a while.
Tried this the other night.  It reminds of a rodenbach or a duchuos duborgois.  A belgian red ale with a nice malty charecter.  Sweeter then it is tart, yet subtle and very nice to drink.
A light beige head tops off a reddish brown body.  The nose is malty, some berries, dried fruit, hops.  Soft carbonation, medium body, slightly watery.  Flavor was a bit coarse and unpleasant.

Pours honey brown with sweet french toast on the nose. Full nectar with minimal froth yet ample residual effers. Tastes like grandma¬ís french toast smothered in maple syrup and fresh berries. Well ballanced. Alcohol is well hidden. Long semi sweet finish. Tastey.

Good oak colored body with a medium volume light tan head.  Coffee, malts, and tea accents are most present in the aroma.  Great taste, caramel, toffee, light malts.... this is somewhat similar to the Westy 12.  Light alcohol burn in the ending, though it‚Äôs mostly sweet.
Cleare dark cherry color with a medium creamy off-white head. Aroma of spice and sweet malt. Sweet spiced flavor some hints of fruit.

Looks nice in the glass, an orange-brown color, wit a medium pitted, wispy head. Curious aroma, hints at caramel, bread dough, nuts, plums, coconut, nutmeg and/or thyme. Big fluffy sweetness up front, coupled with a palate-stinger from the alcohol and moderate high effervescence. Finish is very smooth and light, but with some alcohol...as Belgians go, it doesn¬ít mask the alcohol as well as the best, but it¬ís still a pleasing finish. Warming in the chest. Really feels like a cold weather beer, not terribly appropriate on this warm spring night, not that I¬ím enjoying it any less. Very even tempered, without being overly complex, but still possesses alot of the rich qualities you want in a strong Belgian. Perhaps approaches some of the famous strong trappistes, but definitely rougher. Made a nice match with strong roquefort cheese.

thick head, dark color, parts of a good wine, lots of fruit, some spices, some complex other parts, fully natural.
 ..a very nice one

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2007 pours dark brown with a large creamy light tan head, aroma of belgian style spices, citrusy fruit, caramel sweet malts, and some dark fruitts. flavor is smooth for 8.5%, citrusy, caramel malts stick out with there sweetness, good body, good brew.

Dark bown ale with a thick off white head. Wonderful aroma of coriander, orange peels, and caramel. In mouth, rich and warm malt, candi sugar, coriander, curacao, licorice, and plums. Nice alcohol warmth develops. Rich bodied, with a lightly oily moutfeel. Bottle at l¬íAutre Oeil, March, 3 2006.

33cl - thanks to secret santa cousin Rich -  Aroma is nutty, toffee, carmel, and malt.  Pours deep brown with a small head and great lacing.  Flavor matches aroma.  Palate is sticky and chewy.  Strong and flavorful.
330 ml bottle, at de Klomp, Nice, France. Deep ruby colour, large head. Malty sweet aroma, notes of caramel. Malty sweet flavour, notes of molasses and sweet wine.

Dark brown color, with a tan-colored head, with a spicy nose of orange peels, dates ,figs fruitiness, chocolate malt, roasted malt, and an alcoholic hint in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate, with a sweet roasted malt, burnt brown sugar, bitter chocolatey note, candied orange peels, dark dried fruits, toffeish accent, with a subtle coffee touch, and an alcoholic strenght well hidden behind his sweet malty character, leading towards a sweet dark fruits fruitiness and a shy bitter hops finish.

750ml bottle.  Pours a dark amber with a thick frothy head.  The aroma is very sweet and spicy.  The taste is sweet, with a touch of alcohol, but a nice finish that lingers just enough.  Excellent beer.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 Bottled. Much compact and creamy head, optimal duration. Intense black color, impenetrable and elegant one. Overbearing alcoholic and complex scent; notes of burned wood, spices... much flowery. Solid and wrapping taste, excessive alcoholic and with medium fizz. Notes of caramel and sweet malt with roasted sugar and liqueur rumors. Interesting but with too many excesses.

[ Bottled ; chilled ; fresh ]
mostly diminushing large creamy tan head that tops up a muddy medium brown body. Heavy lacing. Few thick Particules. Bottle conditioned Aroma is heavy roasted , toasted, molasse, creamy, plum, dates, figs while hops are light spruce and yeast is light earth. . Initial flavor is moderate sweet while being balanced afterward Finish is medium. Wonderful body.. creamy and thick texture... 

Definitly over average belgian

Bottle.
Hazy brown coloured with a beige head.
Sweet aroma of dried fruits with notes of chocolate and spices.
Flavour of dried fruits with notes of alcohol and spices.
Good, but could use more body.

Pours dark brown with a mostly receding tan head. Aroma of plums, figs, sweet yeasty bread, earthy toffee malt, and rye. Taste is vinous malts and oak with dark Belgian fruits. Notes of candied fruits, dusty yeast, and bread. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lush carbonation. Subdued alcohol note. Very enjoyable!

Intense and warming with flavors of dried fruits, plums, dates, figs, raisins, molasses, brown sugar, orange rind, and very prominent alcohol fumes that intensifies as it warms.   Very sticky, almost cloying mouthfeel.   To be sipped slowly and savored, except that slows down the process of ordering and enjoying a second one!

Pours a deep red-prune colour...says its supposed to be copper? Nice fluffy head above the clouds. Smooth malts, molasses, some rum qualities, sugar and lots of dark fruit. very well balanced and heavily enjoyable.  Some smooth sweet chocolate undertones for the aftertaste. This is a well balanced and clean, yet chewy brew. Didn¬ít even realize I had finished it and was a bit sad I didnt get more. the 8% really bounces in after a while on ya:) wooOOoOO

(33cl bottle) Pours a huge, frothy, tan head that doesn¬ít quit. The body is a deep reddish brown. The nose hints of fresh figs, jamaican molasses, barrel-aged bourbon, lemons and plums. Very sweet - maple syrup, refined sugar and caramel. I¬íd definitely rejoin this beer for another tasting.

This poured the color of root beer popsicles and looked nice & fancy in the gold rimmed glass with the gold "Gouden Carolus" emblem.  It smelled of plums and raisins with maple somewhere in the taste or smell as it warmed.  The flavor was smokey wtih citrus on the back of my tongue and smooth alcohol, not bitter or overpowering.  It had a honeyish texture and was vaguely Meditteranean in theory (or at least what I think meditteranean would taste like when I read books set there).  I had this on tap at the Maple Tree, but would enjoy having it on hand.

Pours a reddish brown beer with a small but persisting beige, creamy head. Huge banana-toffee aroma, also notes of grapes and a small note of alcohol. Sweet taste, chocolate-dipped grapes, good malts. Low level of carbonation, which I usually quite like, it really brings on the taste better. Medium to wellbodied, slight alcoholburn. Delightful, truly deserves it¬ís reputation.

Aroma is sweet fruit with something that¬ís almost tart.  I¬íd say it¬ís sour apple way in the background.  Hint of alcohol in the pour. The tartness is less prevelant in the flavor.  Soft mouthfeel.  Very fruity (red fruit...can¬ít pick it out exactly) and very nice overall.

Dark brown, slightly red colored, medium sized beige head. Licorice, and nice warming medium alcohol in aroma, also with spices,  chocolate and some sweetness, fine aroma. Medium to full bodied. Licorice, sweetness, medium alcohol, spices in flavor, sweetness lasts in aftertaste with medium alcohol and mild licorice.

Dark brown with a ruby tinge. Medium sized beige head with some lace. Strong aroma with banana, toffee, licorice and red wine. There¬ís a good balance in the flavour, with the sweet toffee, some bitterness and maybe a touch of sour. Nice and solid medium to strong body, with a lively but mostly pleasant carbonation level. Well contained alcohol, and a rather well constructed beer all round.
750ml bottle at Kramer¬ís.  Rich fruity aroma and big malty flavor.  Figs, raisins, lots of classic dark belgian flavor.  Hints at the alcohol content but hides the 8.5 well.  Good stuff.

Bottle, at DBF2004 (040515).
Redbrown with light brown head. Aroma moderate malty (caramel) and hoppy. Flavours moderate sweet and bitter. Medium to full body, high gravity.
Dark red with a frothy lasting off white head. The aroma is sweet and kinda like juicyfruit gum with a sweet with hints of malt and toffee....very nice.

Bottle shared with tupalev. Pours a murky reddish-brown with a spare off-white head. Sweet aroma of caramel malt, brown sugar, fruit and alcohol. Nice rich flavour of caramel malt -- it¬ís delicious. Surprisingly smooth for an 8% beer. Excellent!

Draft @ Woodward Ave Brewery.  Nice brown color, small white head.  Very complex nose.  Picked up fruity mixed with bubblegum.  Taste is very complex, and with a peppermint finish.  Even with the high alchohol which I normally don¬ít like, I thoroughly enjoyed this one.  Really liked it.

Bottle courtesy of and shared with Blankboy.  Dark brown, thin tan head.  Strong sweet aroma.  Strong sweet taste. A little stale in the aftertaste.  Wonderfully strong sweet Belgian Ale that had more in common with a recent Fuller¬ís Vintage than the classic strong Belgian Ale taste in my opinion.  Just a little staleness kept it from achieving greatness.

Big beige head, dark brown with maybe a slight red hue. Aroma of alcohol albeit somewhat subdued.  It seems like there is some fruit to be picked up but the alcohols takes it out, might in part be due tothe fact that it is being served at about 60.   IT has a big sweet flavor that crawls across your tongue.  Very smooth and well balanced.  I¬ím not posittive of the vintage.  I¬íve had the bottle for about a year.  The  alcohols in the aroma are a detraction to me, however I certainly would try it again served a touch cooler.

Draft @ Woodward Ave Brewery in Ferndale. Pours a speckled brown color with a foamy off white head. Nose is estery, light bubblegum, bananas, dark fruits, light yeast. Taste is doughy, some sweetness, toffee, banana, and an alcohol warming finishes it up. Some light peppermint is even noticed throughout.

Pitch brown color with a finger¬ís worth of foam floating on top.  Nice aroma of plums and cherries.  Strong sweet malt taste with more earthy fruit tones on the end.  Yeast and bread play a part in the middle with some toffee finish.  Very nice.
Bottle. Malty, green apple aroma. Dark brown colour. Quite sweet flavour, some fruitiness. Not that nice.
This ale is smooth on the palate and light on carbonation.  The lightly sweet metalic flavor lingers between citrus and bourbon.

Bottle:  Excellent aroma of fruit, toffee, light chocolate, and a hint of yeast.  Pours a dark transparent amber with a small off-white head.  Fruit, raisin, light chocolate, toffee, and yeast.  Light alcohol flavor and moderate warmth come into play in the finish.

11.2oz bottle 2004: Dark plummy brown with a big tan topping of delicate foam. Fades to a big collar and whispy skimming on top and the lacing is drippy with a textured webbing lightly leaving spots and strings as it dwindles.

Murky, dark aroma of plummy stuff and lightly vinous qualities with a nice notion of mint-like yeasty spice, some molasses and cooking sugars, and purple grape juice.

Taste is quite nice here; clean, unwavering, very well rounded with dark candied sugar flavors as plum, currant, and raisin mix in with a lightly chewy fruit cake backing drizzled with caramel and light spices. Slivers of orange creep around the back end as it warms slightly with a tiny backwash of black licorice and some residual brown sugar pinches. Nice!

Feel is perfect. Super clean with a lightly bready, chewy center that holds a very solid medium heft and great length in sugary dark candied fruits. Nice gradual build up to the warming kick in the finish that reminds you you¬íre drinking a Belgian beer. Wonderfully slick, quick, and tasty.

I would if I could, drink a bunch of this stuff, but the 8% does hit a bit later with a bit of warmth. Oh so nice a drinker though. Gone in no time. A solid Belgian brew.

Big, offwhite, creamy head with large bubbles; body clear dark red. Deep aroma of caramel, bread, and spice.  Taste is broad and sweet, with some alcohol heat, settling into an aftertaste with faint roastiness and lots of spice. Licorice. Nice balancing aftertaste, which lingers. Excellent! One of the best beers made.

I wasn¬ít planning on rating this.  I grabbed what I thought was the Carolus triple, and then noticed it was pouring red-brown.  Oops.  I find their triple too sweet for my taste, but this was marginally better.  The syrupy notes were still there, but the addition of some darker malts gave it some raisiny, plummy, figgy, date, and dough flavors.  The finish was a little murky, and I would appreciated some more hops, but overall a little better balanced than the triple and easier to drink.  A ton of yeast, though.

Pours an excellent dark brown with good lacing. Aroma is full with loads of dark fruits and molasses kicking about. Taste is mmm, theres soemthign wrong here, similar to aroma, but with a kind of bitter malt whiskey liquirce distorting the goodness. Maybe this bottle wasn at its best but the taste just wasnt living upto what the aroma had to give.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark brown, creamy head. Lovely malty aroma with chocolate, vanilla, raisins, banana. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Warming finish. Very good indeed.

This is a quality brew, pouring a deep nutty brown body with a dense, fizzy tan head.  The aroma is toffee with raisins and brown sugar and a hint of alcohol with mayhaps a touch of chocolate. Slightly spritzy in the mouth, it delivers a flavor of sweet toffee, dark fruits, burnt brown sugar, some chocolate, a bit of smokey woodiness, and white peppers.  The finish is sweet and alcohol warm.  Very good.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Frankfort, IL<font size=-1>
Deep red-brown. Slight beige head. Alcoholic toffeyish sweet aroma. The flavour is sweet caramel with a touch of smoked barley. Notes of chocolale and lemon.

Big tan fluffy head.  Dark brown in color. Sweet malty, dark fruit aroma.  Heavy in the mouthfeel. Assortment of flavors, toffee, coffee, chocolate and plums.  Alcohol is subdued.  Rich in the end with some lingering fruit notes and spicy texture. A nice flavorfull beer. Hate to see this beer might leave the phoenix area with no distributor.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2017 Feb 2017
Easy to forget the classics. Sweet milk chocolate early, some Belgian stink, low fizz, very smooth. Can¬ít drink ¬íem all day but great fun.
Vintage: September 2006
Consumed: January 2009
3 years looks about right for this beer. Fresh bottlings have shown a heavy palate with plenty of ¬ístewed fruit¬í malts but some medium term cellaring has certainly lightened the beer up. Aromas show a lot of life with funky, meaty, stinky malts and a hint of sarsparella. Chocolate, licorice and cola flavours emerge early in the palate but the intensity thins out as a woody note kicks in. Nice sliver of chocalate runs right through the palate. Not convinced additional cellaring will enhance the beer further.
Vintage: unknown
Consumed: September 2005
Thin head, light coffee in colour.  Body is very dark brown. Shows ok lacing. Nose is quite rich, candied, heavy, slightly ¬ístewed¬í malts. Heavy weight palate with lots going on, good complexity. Starts out relatively light early in the palate with more heavy, slightly roasted malts but then transcends to some excellent licorice. People talk about licorice in shiraz but this beer shows much better (and obvious) flavour definition. Finishes just a touch short with some alcohol burn, this in itself is not a deal breaker.

Bottle. Dark brown/red beer withthin beige head. Choc and dark malts with some fruit and winey nose. Slightly sweet in mouth. Finish is ultimately very hoppy and dry with more choc/wine. Got better as the beer went on.

Light understated aroma. Hops, brown sugar, musty yeast, mild fruits. Pours a beautiful reddish-copper, carbonated, tan head that sticks around. Smokiness, sweet fruit up front. Mid-range body. Alcohol is well hidden. Sweetish aftertaste. Clean finish. Very enjoyable.

Bottle: Poured a dark color beer with a thick foamy brown head with excellent retention. Aroma of figs with sweet alcohol notes and typical Belgian yeast is easily identifiable and greatly enjoyable. Taste is quite rich with figs and plum sweetness with a thick body and warm alcohol note mix with lots of yeast. Very enjoyable though not my favourite from this fine brewery.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2005 Bottle (330ml).  Poured a murky orange-brown, some sediment, decent creamy tan head - leaves a pretty light tan lacing behind.  Aroma oaky, resiny, with masses of musty, brown sugary, caramel malt, some sour wine, oil-based paint, various fruits and spices, some alcohol, even a hint of peat - very woody and mysterious.  Taste is extremely malty, toffee/caramel, brown sugar; the alcohol asserts itself quickly, but settles into a decent balance with the malt and a medley of spices and fruits, also a bit leafy and woody.  But this is *malt*, my friends - "suffer or leave".  Mouthfeel is primarily alcholic and sticky, but it¬ís got decent body too, as well as enough carbonation to suit me.  I¬íd rate this higher, but I was expecting more complexity based on the nose.  Still highly recommended.

Dark brown with a small, tight head. Aroma was bready with a hint of banana. Fruity taste, very sweet, with coffee notes and just a touch of dryness. I found there was just a bit too much frothy carbonation in the mouthfeel. Otherwise a delightful strong ale.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2007 A Mes rate:
Draught @ PBF. Excellent. Wonderful dubbel - amber type looks with thick tan head that lasts very well. One of the best looking beers I have seen. Typical Gouden Carolus behaviour all round. Nose is rich with plums and yeast and a touch of hard liquor and an absolute delight. Some may find it a little over bearing maybe. Initially sweet but then all the good bits come through with plums and malt and coffee and plenty of other good stuff. Full bodied, excelent palate full stop. Warm boozy hit for the finish but just done perfectly. Get some it‚Äôs glorious!

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2010 Sampler from bottle at <a href=http://ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/orland-par Orland Park, Yep, a dark brown color that gives no clue as to the stuff within. Taste is sweet; dark, but not roasty. Has an excellent all-around "beer" taste. Can also pick out a few deliberately staled hops.

75cL bottle. Clear dark copper hue with good head and lacing. Citrus/orange and spicy nose with some bread dough notes. Starts off with a spicy and citrus note and then goes to a bread, yeasty finish. Creamy texture and finish. Good beer.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2006 Best before 07/12/06.  Dark brown beer with a ruby tint.  Nice sweet fruity and malty aroma, plum/prune, caramel/toffee apple, black pepper and cardamon.  Full bodies, malty sweetness, plummy with heavy notes of bread and toast.  Lingering yeasty spice, a bit of wheaty tartness and some other fruity acidity.  Nice complexity.

Tap at Mugs Ale House.  I wanted to re-rate this with a few more years on it, so here it is.  Deep brown with a ruby tint.  Nose is peppery and lightly alcoholic over sweet slightly oxidized malts.  Sherryish and pruney with sweet dried fruit in back.  Plums and raisins on the nose.  The flavour is still very sweet with brown sugar and dried fruits.  Slightly alcoholic which helps cut the sweetness, but it¬ís still too sweet and chewy.  I thought that some age would have dried this out, but it doesn¬ít seem to have done that.  It has added some nice sherry character to the sweet maltiness.  I don¬ít think it¬ís going to improve with any more age on it though.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2005 A beautiful dark colour, with a nice taste of chocolade, brown sugar, fruit and a bit of raisons. There is a little alcohol noticable but it isn¬ít misplaced. A nice beer overall. (Bottle 33cl)

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2005 My new favorite beer.  Beautiful brown caramel color.  Toffee chocolate smell which mirrors the taste. It is a little thin in body.  If the body was thicker it would be perfect.  Malty Butterscotch toffee taste.  Gets sweeter as the taste flows.  Excellent!!!!  Tasted at Bieres & Compagnie 4350 St. Denis, Montreal.

33 cl Bottle. Storage 2 year. Beautiful in dark brown colour, and a dense brown head. Wonderful aroma of choclate and dried fruit. Complex in taste and hints of toffe and choclate and a warm aftertaste. Really a great beer.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2006 Pours a fairly thick brown body with a small head. Aroma is mostly dark fruits and yeast. Spices, banana and alcohol there as well. Flavor is the same, very smooth and enjoyable.
This dark brown ale poured with a modest tan head, eliciting a fruity malt aroma. There is a sweet coffee/banana flavor with a smooth malt finish. This is a very nice brew.

Bottle.  Cloudy pour mahogany color with a golden-brown head.  Bold aroma/flavor combination!  Lots of apple/pear presence, figs, peach, maple syrup.  The perfect amount of alcohol presence to give it some bold kick.  Firm mouthfeel, very well done.  A good beer for celebrating something, which I¬ím doing right now!

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2011 330ml bottle yields a cloudy, dark copper colored ale with a large tan head.  This ale left some excellent lacing.  Aroma is caramel, molasses and hint of alcohol.  The initial palate is quite sweet, giving way to fruity esters of overripe banana, raisin and, perhaps, port wine.   Full bodied and smooth, this ale has a long-lasting, moderately hopped finish and warm alcohol coda.  Initial Rating Date: 6/17/2005 3.9

Update (12/1/2011):  This beer is needs the right vessel.  I used the Chimay goblet-style glass.  There are some very strong aromas and lingering flavors of dark cherry in here that I missed in the first review.  This is a wonderful beer cloaking a rather high ABV (8.5%).  It¬ís great as a fall or winter warmer....
Aroma of caramel and caramel.  Yes... omphs of depth and flavours but give me a Cazech pils any day.

Bottle. YEAH BABY!! Deep cloudy dark brown (poured in all the yeast) with good head and plenty of lace. Smells DIVINE, sweet dark smooth brown sugar, rum and raisins. Tastes even better, smooth, sweet then dry and crisp. Almost perfect palate with a slightly warm and dry alcoholic finish. God this stuff is good; Trios Pistols sans the slightly off bits. YUM!

Pours a huge off white head with excellent lacing, colour is Dark amber/brown. This beer looks stunning in the glass. Aroma is dominated by plumb and a bit of yeast, quite strong actually. First sip is pretty sweet on the tongue, plenty of other flavours.. Plums, raisins, a bit of coffee or chocolate. Finish is quite strong, with the alcohol coming through and providing some warmth. Brilliant.
Rum and raisin thick sweet aroma. Spicy tang balancing the thick malts, coffee, rum and raisin. This is very good. May sneak off and grab some more.

Bottle: Burnt orange, brownish, medium foamy beige head, attractive lacing. ¬† Huge plum and licorice aroma. ¬† Soft notes of other dark pitted fruit as well. ¬† Dark and pale fruit on the tongue, both strong. ¬† Soft licorice and even chocolate is present. ¬† Fairly sweet up front, with a soft hop bitterness on the back end. ¬† Fairly big body, with a moderate mouthfeel. ¬† Plum, apple skin, minor maple syrup, and chocolate all linger after the finish. ¬† I wish I had two or three bottles of this. &nbsp Simply delicious!

33 cl bottle, bbe 5th Aug 06. Turbid brown with a strong red shine, small off-white head, sparkling. Malty and sticky odour with a lot of brown bread. Beautiful flavour of caramel and carob with gentle hop bitterness towards the end. Full body, a bit (too) sticky texture.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2006 (Bottle 33 cl) Deep reddish brown colour, light brown head. Very refinened malty charamel flavours well balanced with the hops. Extremely high gravity and hence a very full body. A very refined Belgian Ale with lots of sweetness, but never cloying.  When I first had this in 1993 it was just called "Gouden Carolus" at 7% ABV and came in a bottle with no label. In 1997 it was changed to "Gouden Carolus - Carolus D¬íOr" at 7,5% ABV and now it¬ís called "Gouden Carolus Classic" at 8,5% ABV. So it has changed quite a bit but is still a truly Belgian classic. 240793
UPDATED: JUL 19, 2005 bottled.  big aroma w/ caramel, coffee and roasted barley.  full bodied.  notes of chocolate and malt.

deep brown red color, firm head. Interesting aroma, very belgian, yeasty, raisins, hops, malt, plums, vanilla and fruits. Taste is very filling, a bit yeasty but balanced out with malt, maybe some fruits balanced out with the bitterness of chocolate or something like that, incredible body and oh so nice on the tongue, world class brew
Deep reddish colour with a small tan head. Malty and sweet aroma with hints of plum. Nice balanced flavor with yeast and a malty dark fruit sweetness.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2005 This is one that I will try a little more often. Nice rich aroma. A beautiful reddish brown appearance. Moderately sweet flavor. Medium body. The head doesn¬ít stick around long. I Like it!!!
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2006 It was strongbut it has the almostsame flavor than the Keizer, but it was ok. The beer did not stop flowing until I served it. I do not like that.

Thin yellowish head. Dark brown and red coloring. The aroma is massive with pears and vanilla. There are also dates and black walnuts. The mouthfeel is rich and creamy. The taste is full of prunes and pears with some slightly spicy nutmeg in the finish. Slight paper like finish. Smooth is the best way to describe this winner. Certainly a quality made beer with the alcohol well hidden.

Thin head which reduces to a wisp of foam on the surface rather quickly.  Very good carbonation.  Great aroma!  Rich with dark fruit, black cherries, yeast, molasses, plums, you name it.  Bit of brandy also.  Color is a dark mahagony brown.  Flavor is a bit weak for the great aroma.  Malty, yeasty, dry with a nice alcohol warming.  Finish is actually short lived and slightly dry and grassy.  A good belgian that starts out like a great winner and falls a little short.

Good depth and complexity in a very esy drinking package. Balnced candy sweetness with rich plums and and brandy notes. Nice malt with clean mouthfeel and sofft finish. A light touch of floral hop  and background spice. Very creamy vanilaa nougat and toffee on the finish with some lingering fruit notes.
Pours dark brown hue with a frothy tan head.  Aromas of yeast, candi sugar and caramel.  Flavors of plums, oaky and roasted malts.  A surprise.

Corked bottle. Clouded crimson. Small foamy tan head. Nose is very sweet. Candy sugar, ripened dark fruits, sweet malts, hints of caramel, and light woody notes. Taste is also sweet and very pleasant. Dark fruits, candy sugar, brown sugar, caramel, malt, and light flowery notes. Some very faint woody notes come through at points as well. Body is medium but very carbonated. Mild creaminess. Finish is more sweet notes - big candy sugar, brown sugar, caramel, malts, and dark fruits. Nice beer!
Yeasty, dark and nutty with candied fruit in the nose. Flavour is coffee dark chocolate with a salty oaky finish.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2005 Bubblegum, chocolate, mixed berries, biscuity malt and candy-like icing sugar in the doughy, yeasty aroma.  Opaqu, dark brown coloured body is topped by generous, large-bubbled, tan head that recedes slowly to lasting cover with some lacing.  Fruity esters suggest pears and apples with plenty of chocolate flavour.  Fruity esters become wonderfully more pronounced as it warms.  Medium body with soft carbonation that tickles the tongue and smooth, creamy mouthfeel.  A true pleasure to drink.  Bottle (Bieropholie - Feb. 2005).
Brown creamy head on a drak brown body. Stout and strong, but with notes of spices. A very nice strong dark beer for long evenings.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2005  Pours a dark brown which resembles a cup of tea.  The head is obviously creamier then tea.  The aroma is primarily fruity.  It is like tea but has a bit of spice to it.  The taste is very sweet and very much like apple, berries, and green tea.  The mouthfeel has a nice spicy feel to it which works quite effectively.  Overall I am impressed but not blown away.

Aroma:spicy and chocolate,caramel  
Appearance:dark brown good head. 
Flavor:Caramel,chocolate small bitterness,alcohol.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2005 Rerate 24/10/05: Damn it¬ís great to come back to a beer and discover it¬ís even better than you first thought. This looked great, mahogany with a tall creamy head that left great swathes of lace. The aroma showed molasses, grape juice, banana and peppery alcohol. Terrific initial mouthfeel, thick and creamy. Lots of dried fruit on the tongue, with some treacle, orange and a big slug of that 8.5% abv. Sherry notes and hoppy bitterness in the warming finish. A very delicate balancing act. (33cl bottle, Balmain Village Cellars, bb 2/3/08)

Huge cotton candy and bubble gum aromas in the aroma -- this stuff smells like the day I spent working a concession stand at a carnival.  Muddy, murky,  ruddy appearance with tinge of amber and lots of haziness.  NIce sugary sweetness with a little acidic souness and plenty more hops than I would anticipate.  Nice overall mouthfeel and a pleasant warmth.  A very good brew.

Draft at CAH.  Medium brown, OK head.  Aroma of wood and faint dark fruit, and a note of dried hops.  Flavor was also quite woody, some malt, and more undefined dark fruits.  Somehow, not quite in balance, the flavors just didn¬ít meld.  Could improve with a bottle that has been aged a bit.  Incidentally, it was much better with food, as the wood notes fell back and fruit flavors of currants came forward.  Rating based upon drinking without food.
Bottle.  Red-brown, hazy with medium tan head and lacing.  Lovely Caramel aroma.  Flavor is light, caramel and alcohol in aftertaste.  Sweet finish.  Good beer.
Rich and warming aroma with plenty of alcohol and caramelised oranges.  Pours a deep ruby with a shrinking off-white head and sticky lace.  The body is sweet, toffeeish and a tad cloying.

Bottle at Plan B. Cph. Dk. Red-brown color with a big tan head. Sweet caramel fruity aroma and sweet dry light alcoholic fruity caramel yeasty taste. Medium to full body and a sweet warming alcoholic finish.

Deep brown, clear, with a good-sized tan head. Nice sweet nose, with chocolate, grapes, and light licorice or anise notes. Flavor is sweet, with some cider, a touch of anise, raisins, bready yeast, and a good deal of bitterness.
Rich, decadently sweet offering.   Caramel, dark fruit, and orange.   Alcohol well hidden.  Cloying? Maybe, but I like this stuff.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2009 Murky brown color with a thin light brown head. Complex and appealing aroma of raisin and figs, sugar, malt and bubble guml. Very rich and enjoyable flavor of figs, malt , raisin, bubble gum and alcohol. Full body, liquorous texture, lively carbonation. Amazing stuff, this is truly a dessert in its own.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2005 better than a wine, better than a port. Beautiful wine dark. Like a great barleywine, and can be aged for years more.Gorgeous aroma, cherries. Sweet raisin, plum, light brown sugar dry mix. Complementary spices of clove and cinammon wit cherry. Can drink anytime for satisfaction. Medium mouthfeel, not overpowering.This is not the same as the Classic.

75cl bottle. Ruddy brown shines brilliant scarlet as the glass hits the light. Rapidly disappearing off-white head. Clove-ish sweet aroma with more than a touch of something medicinal and woody. Sweetness though the flavour, and yes it¬ís yeasty, plummy, spicy, pugh pugh barney mcgrew cuthbert dibbele and grub-y, still subtler than other belgians, carries it off with a sweet ¬ín sour panache. And three quarters of a litre is very, very enjoyable.

Pours cloudy red with a quickly disipating tan head. Clove light fruity red wine, cherry, yeast, brown sugar aroma. Sweet but not cloying. Excellent follow through.Yeast, cheese, oak fruit. A little smoke? Gorgeous.

Draught:  This one poured a dark reddish-brown with a thick creamy off-white head.  I was suprised that the aroma was a bit weak for the style.  There were some noted of fruits (plums et. al.) and caramel.  The tatse was much better than the aroma.  It had a caramel sweetness, with fruits in the background.  The after-taste was a bit sour/tart.  A very nice beer.

At the KULMINATOR in Antwerp. An outstanding Vintage bottle of Gouden Carolus 1987. Afther all these years still very young and aromatic. Great appearance, very nice fluffy froth and brilliant dark red-wood color. Fine aroma¬ís of raisins and old port with a nice Bee-wax touch, also a fine hint of Sauternes wine, dates and figgs. Medium mouthfeel with an outstanding balance between sweet and sour. In the taste also Port hints, raisins, Cox apples and fine sweet asian spices.
This is the Carolus like in the old days.

The color is delightful. It is bright but gloomy and displays shades of orange, burgundy, green and maroon. Initially the lacing and head retention struggled but I poured the beer into my St. Bernardus Goblet instead of my Gouden Carolus chalice (The glass I poured it in to begin with) and everything was much improved. The lace was amazing. The type of lace that you have to scrub off the next time you wash it because it stuck and dried throughout the night. Yeah.

The aroma is enjoyable. Delicate fruit and spice. Lots of fruit in the aroma, especially plums and oranges. The malt provides a lot of sweet scents. Lovely. 

Very dynamic flavor. Licorice characteristics up front, red and black, but mainly black. Caramel and toffee come about next and shortly there after, it moves to the fruit with plums and candied coated raisins. The finish is moderately yeasty, somewhat dull and displays flavors of banana and cookie crumb with a well known alcohol kick. I really like this stuff. It tastes very good. I have been very impressed with Anker¬ís offerings so far and am planning on visiting the brewery while in Belgium this summer.

10.01.04  750ml Bottle.  Cloudy, pressed-cider brown with big, lasting, khaki head.  Luscious aromas of banana bread, ripe plum, carrots cooked in brown sugar and butter.  Soft body like freshly whipped cream followed by a crisp hop bitterness and slight astringency.  Medium sweet and sugary.  A complex conundrum for a strong ale, the sweet/dry mix makes for a pleasant and refreshing brew, however it is unsettling at times.

Dirty brown with a hint of a prettier colour like orange or red. The bottle had been knocked over in the past 2 days and shaken a bit. Fair starting head. Aroma of alcohol with musty fruit beneath. Refreshing for the high alcohol content. Must be drunk at warmer termperatures. Very nice palate and refined mild flavour. No overwhelming flavours. A nice balance of fruit, malt and light spice. A noble drink.

Pours a hazy mahongoany hue, cool woody brown, with a with a nice bit of froth, if short-lived.
Aroma, sour, citric, and spicy, from the start, lemon peel, clove, and pepper.
Taste: big, brisk, fruity blast on the palate, softly fading into a firm malt base. Cherries, berrries, bananas, melon, all accompanied by a tidy peppery kick on the side, and the flavor never fades, nestles well in the mouth, offering a resilient, bright tingle on the tongue. Great texture, wonderful play on the palate, a genial joust of tastes in the mouth. Fruity, to the point of being wine-like, but with plenty of it¬ís own individual charms to make it a supple, special little thing in the mouth. Very special ale, hunt it down, if you must!

Bottle pours a slightly hazy garnet color with a decent beige head and very good lace.  The aroma is malty, yeasty, raisin, and spicy.  The flavor starts sweet, has a dried fruit ditty, a yeast accent, a slight hop blip, and quite nice.  The palate is Belgain Strong Ale rich and cleansing.  Overall, very nice.  It is on my shopping list.  Thanks Ryan at Cellars!

UPDATED: APR 21, 2006 Re-rate Feb 25th 2006

Sweet sugar/cola aroma with mild spice, brown sugar and floral notes. Cloudy brown with faint red hints. Smooth candy sugar, alcohol, molasses, rum, bread pudding, rum-raisin cake, dark fruits and yeast. Still an amazingly flavorful beer. Alcohol is hotter than I remember, but the flavor is still amazing July 9th 05 re-rate:

Probably my palate had evolved, but this is a fantastic beer. It tastes like X-mas. Rum raisin flavors predominate, but malty bread pudding is in there too. This is quickly becoming a favorite.

Original Rating

Bottle courtesy of Matta. Thanks. Sweet slightly spicy, alcoholic aroma. Beautiful dark brown color. Almost looks like heavily concentrated tea. Sweet and incredibly smooth taste. Highly drinkable and even has a bit of a hop finish. Real nice beer.
Good dark brown colored looks. Tastes of coffee, toffee, caramel and cherry.

Bottled (BB 02/2007)
Clear ruby color, big off-white head. Aroma has grapefruit, raisins and malt. Sweetish balanced palate: sugar, toffee, alcohol. Full-bodied and pleasant.

Pours almost black with a creamy tan head.  Aroma heavy on yeast and sweet caramel.  Flavor is sweet and malty, with a fruity/vinous character and a hoppy, dry finish.  Nothing spectacular, but a good, solid Belgian.

Pours a substantial, full and frothy head that dissipates rather quickly. A golden orange color with some haze, and an adequate amount of CO2. A resilient clinging lace. Rich fruity smell, with some hints of orange and yeast. The flavor is fruity sweet, almost syrupy, yet tart, with a lasting biting finish. The alcohol is well hidden, yet the warming effects can be felt quickly. The mouth feel was effervescent, lively and also creamy. A good beer with a distinct character, although I do not really care for the contrasting bite.
8 May 2004 - Luscious spiritous fruit malt aroma. Semi cloudy dark brown colour. Swwet long hop complex flavour.  Lovely body with a long lingering taste. Like a fortified wine that warms the throat.
Very sweet aroma, lots of caramel, cherries, toasted malts. Galvor is very sweet, lots of caramel, figs. Just too cloying for me.
Poured a dark reddish brown with a huge off white head. Malty, fruity and bready aromas. Sweet, spicy, and fruity tasting. Alcohol well hidden. Very good

Neutral stale fruity nose.
Hazy brown, creamy head.
Rye bread flavors, nuts,  preserved fruit, a hint of vegetable.
Medium body, fizzy mouthfeel.

Clear ruby-brown pour. Medium light brown head with decent lacing. Huge malty nose, tons of dark fruits, toasted notes, chocolatey richness, maybe even coffee, caramel and grapes reminiscent flavors, very estery anyway. Very appealing and powerful. In mouth, the typical initial Het Anker rich sweetness is luxuriously accompanied by drying out yeast. Smoky, woody and mineral long finish full of memories with an ever so slight alcohol hint and noble hop bitterness. Medium-full bodied, moderate to high carbonation, rich mouthfeel. Fantastic malty belgian, almost like a doppelbock, enormous level of sweetness included. Still, more balanced if not as rich as the grand cru, but perhaps less exciting than the no√´l as far as I¬ím concerned. That¬ís a bit like comparing napoleon and alexander the great though. A must.

Bottle: Dark brown with a heavy beige head. Aroma of burnt coffee and caramel. Alcohol comes through very strong killing all else and not allowing to appreciate anything else. At 8.5% this should not be an issue, it should not be noticable.

Sweet malty and light fruits, vapory, alcohol. Dark brown-red clear with small off-white head.  Medium carbonation in medium body. Starts malty and sweet, with  some fruitiness. Finish is sweet fruity. Light toffee finish, smooth sweet after. Very good.

Gouden Carolus Classic 8.5% alc..
Clear ruby, brownish (cappuccino-like) head, glass sticking but fastly disappearing.
Complex aroma, fruity (plum, dates, sweet cherry), cherry jam, candy sugar, candied orange. 
Candy sugar sweetness, taste of candied fruit, bitter cocoa powder. Sweetness is more balanced by sourness than hop-bitterness.
Light mouthfeel strenght, well balanced, medium body.
[Gouden Carolus 8% alc. 2 years old. Light hazy, ruby colour, head fastly disappears, good lacing.
Aroma is more complex, preserved plum, vinous, candied orange, weak aroma of walnut liquor. Warm spicy in taste, with note of plum, clove, bitter cocoa.
Light to medium body, the same mouthfeelling of the other G.C., very smooth palate. Better than new version, maybe only for the longer maturation? Rate 8-4-8-3-17]

Deep red/brown color, creamy tan head. Aroma of malt, some plum, raisin, yeast. Great malt prescence, some light yeast, plum, vanilla, fairly sweet, bit of caramel and cherry. Comes across as rich and soft, no alcohol detected. The palate really allowed the flavors to gel in such a nice way. High quality stuff. The more I have from this brewery the more I like it.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours a dark red brown colour with little head. Aroma is sweet and malty, plus raisins and caramel. Raisins and caramel also in the taste, plus a roast/burnt sweetness and alcohol. Rounded mouthfeel, slight carbonation. Not bad but too sweet for me.
Reddish brown body, tan head. A good mix of a variety of flavors that make a tasty sweet brew. Give it a shot.

Murky ruby red body, with a small tan head. The aroma reveals raisins, dark fruits, alcohol, toffee and some spices, very nice! Impressive flavor! Sweet, yet its very refreshing, apple, spice, raisin, toffee and a nice alcohol burn in the end. This beer is quite remarkable... Het Anker is becoming one of my favorite Belgian brewers. Very good.

This beer pours a murky orange/red with quickly dissipating carbonation.  Aroma of caramel, toffee, cinnamon, raisin, apple peel, and toasted marshmallow.  The flavor is quite impressive with tangy toffee, raisin, chocolate, and rich caramely bread.  Ethanol highlights the finish, playing off the sweet flavors nicely.  Not as good as their Grand Cru but still a fine beer.
UPDATED: JUN 16, 2004 Ruby-brown, small tan head. Sweet raisins and toffee in aroma. Almonds, raisins, burnt sugar and toffee in flavour. Overly sweet finish, small notes of raisin and burnt wood.

Murky, very dark, brown beer with a vinuous, yeasty, fruity smell.  The taste is sweet, warming, alcoholic and satisfying, with a tasty roundedness.  The sweetness may be a little overpowering but otherwise very drinkable.

Hazy, earthen, copper body with a thin, tan head.  Apples are all over the nose.  I¬ím beginning to see that most of the beers from Het Anker.  Red grape, plum, apricot, fig, caramel, dark candy sugar, whole wheat bread and a light touch of alcohol.  Really, just very fruity.  The body is appropriately thick without becoming cumbersome.  The flavor resides mostly within the realm of sweetness.  A touch of roasted or bitter malt (or the crust of wheat bread) pops in and out, trying to balance.  The bitterness of the hops also try to enter the fray, without much success.  Ultimately, this is a decent Belgian, but one that could use a bit more balance.  Take your time with this one, for time will heal all wounds.

(750 ml)  Pours a copper color with a cloudy body and a medium-sized, creamy, off-white head.  Has a complex aroma of molasses, caramel, grain, mustiness, banana, and vanilla.  Creamy palate.  Has flavors of banana, caramel, and cream.  Delicious!

Don¬ít think that using the term beautiful could be worn out on this one. My attempt to describe it would come no where near doing it the justice it deserves. My only wish is that I could find some in a state closer than Colorado or wherever it may be. Lovely stuff.

My bottle says 8.5%, and its not bottle conditioned. Large head, which goes to almost nothing after a while. Sparkling clear, ruby in colour. Light malt and hops in the aroma. Full bodied, alcohol, moderately sweet, moderately acidic and moderately bitter. A little coffee on the tongue and a face full of bananas. Sampled with sausage, mash & gravy.

330ml bottle: Pours with a moderate, creamy head; heavy cookie, caramel, and yeast aroma; light, slightly piney hop, light doughy, musty yeast; overall, somewhat mild flavor; some dark fruit, wood, licorice, and tobacco flavor; warming alcohol; slight, late bitterness and tartness; what¬ís not to like?!
Hazy deep chestnut color with an off white head. The taste is complex malts and spices with notes of fruit. Has slight alcohol in the finish.

Bottled.
A bit hazy, amber colour.
Complex aroma and flavour from dried and sweet fruits and maybe some chocolate.
Really malty.

Bottle, that says 10.12.05 
Hazy dark amber colour. Sugary, portwine-like aroma. Rich in malts, spicy with notes of raisin and tofee. Still young but very tasty!

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011 A favorite for both my wife and me. We have had it numerous times from a bottle and several times on draft at the Sharp Edge in Pittsburgh.+++ Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer pours a  hazy red/brown with a large tan head. The aroma is malty and very spicy. The flavor is malty with elements of caramel, molasses, nut and chocolate. The flavor is complex and changes as it lingers on the palate.
Spiritus aroma with dark caramel colour and small head. Malt spiritus flavour with smooth finish. Could drink this one all night!

Sample most likely aged for a few years in the store: Pours a full copper brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma of bready Belgian yeast, sweet caramel malt, and some oxidized complexity.  Body starts light and candi sugar sweet with nice balance and complexity, slowing fading into a slightly more dull, earthy dry, bitter finish.  Hides the alcohol very well though, and is quite drinkable.  A nice Belgian strong.

Lightly sedimented brown with a thick solid head. Fruity, earthy yeast aroma, with a little anise? rasiny candy smell. taste is of light rich malt, warming alcohol with roasted bitterness and an anise/spicy flavour lingering
Deep copper color. A warm, fruit-like aroma. Deep wine-like flavor. Raisins, spices, with the taste of alcohol. Not a favorite style, but a good warming winter type of brew.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2006 (Bottled, 0.75l) Quite clear, dark amber color with a small head. Sweetish, malty, slightly alcoholic, candy aroma. Sweet, syrupy-malty, vanilla, pear, candy-toffee flavor, with anise and berry hints, plus some acidity. Black pepper in the aftertaste. Alcohol is very well hidden in the flavor. Smooth, syrupy, slightly ashy palate with a bit foamy carbonation. A nice and balanced brew. Much easier to drink, than the Xmas version, and not nearly as anisey.
(1984 vintage, sampled 3/2006, 7.6% ABV) A thick, extremely malty-syrupy, sweet plum/raisin soup. Some vinous character, too. Definitely not dried out.

Sampled @ Helsinki Beer Festival 2004Copper red, medium beige head. Aroma is very fruity and fresh with notes of sweetness and alcohol. Pretty carbonated palate, full body. Flavor is also fruity with notes of alcohol, sweetness and caramel. Very nice beer and in my opinnion better than Triple.

Thanks again to Hopscotch for sharing. Dark brown, creamy off white head.  Lots of spicy banana nut bread, toffee and caramel.  Rich tasting with notes of fig, raisin, hint of cinnamon french toast (minus the maple syrup).  Full bodied with a nice dry finish. Can't went to try the Grand Cru of the Emperor in the near future. Very tastey!

Fine head on a orange brown body. Aroma of roasted malt, toffee, caramel - sweet and full. Flavor starts sweet but turns nice and bitter hoppy. Distinctive Gouden Carolus flavor (yeast?). A very good and well balanced beer.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2004 Co-rated by scraff...
