Sparkling clear, copper ale with a small, creamy, khaki-colored head. Good retention. The aroma is caramelly, alcoholic and spicy with a huge blast of banana bread with nuts.  The flavor is very bold and malty. The high ABV is well-hidden with notes of milk chocolate, dried prune, raisin, toasted cinnamon, toasted brown sugar and toffee. Well-bittered. Full-bodied with a creamy mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Lengthy, bitter-sweet, dry finish. Thanks to jbrus for the bottle.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2008 (March 2004) 750 ml bottle, no date but purchased a year ago.  Ruddy brown, nearly opaque, largish off-white billowing head.  Massive, wonderful caramel-chocolate-banana aroma that I could bathe in, mmmm.  Yeastiness fairly prominent in the taste alongside a huge caramel malt profile; if I didn¬ít know this was Belgian I¬íd swear it was a doppelbock.  Extremely rich and full-bodied, sweet and decadent as a Viennese torte, this seems quite unlike any other Belgian Strong I¬íve had lately, strange wonderful and unique.  A classic, a masterpiece, fit for kings.

(May 2008):  750 ml bottle from City Market in Burlington, VT, no date that I could see, served at cellar temperature from a Duvel glass.  Stable dark caramel-tinted meringue head fills 2/3 of the glass atop the very dark and nearly opaque maple body....aroma of deeply caramelized sugary malts, chocolat, and apple-banana esters, an enormously complex yeast profile....the body is powerful and full without losing suppleness, without being heavy, chocolaty-caramel with light fruity hints (banana, strawberry perhaps), just the faintest hint of alcoholic tang....low carbonation, juicy, rich and serene, a beautiful slow sipper and every bit as awesome as the first time I had it.  Rating numbers unchanged.

Large beige medium lasting head. Dark brown colour. Aroma is malty, fruity with caramel and raisins notes. Flavor is fruity too with a few light roasty tones, but a bit watery, ending in a short balanced finish. Medium bodied.
Dark amber with big gead. Very nice lacework. Spicy maltiness in the aroma. Mild flavour, rather sweet and fruity. A good alcohol bite finishes this very good beer.
Dark, not much head. Aroma is sweet and dry.Flavor brings a lot of yeast, some fruit and with a bitter finish.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2004 Nice shiny amber color, no head. Has a rather mild and fruity aroma with some yeast. Flavor is great and really brings a lot.It is fruity with some malt, some chocolate, some yeast and a pleasant bitterness.

UPDATED: SEP 9, 2005 hmmm this is a beaut. This beer has a great sweet aroma, chocalately/caramel flavour with a bit of spice. This beer gives a great sense of warmth. This is truly a unique and impressive beer.
re-rate - Still stands the test of time, the banana nose and balance are great and it holds the 8.5% like a champion.

Poured a deep rich brown with a thin head. Beautiful aromas of fruits ( figs, raisins, )toasted malts. The taste is great , raisins   huge malt flavour, sweet, soft carbonation, thick full mouthfeel. Man, this was tasty !!

Hazy dark brown pour, with a huge white head comprised of small bubbles, and nice lacing.  Very nice nose. Fruit (grapes/ winelike,) hops, mellow malts and small hints of dough/bread.  Grapes stand out a bit more in the flavor, almost seeming more plumlike. The wine similarity is there as well. Malts come out a little more as does the yeast and breadiness. Some spices; cloves and a little coriander. A nice rich body, spice filled palate, overall a very smooth beer. Very well balanced.
Clear brown in color. Fruity aroma. REally enjoyable beer. SMooth in flavor. Fruity aroma like raisins. Very well made beer. Really good.

Pours a clear brown with a lucious tan head and a glass coating lacing. Raisiny fruity aroma and on the sweet end of the spectrum. Smooth creamy malty flavor with fruity sweet overtones. This is a great dessert beer and very well made.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Sweet notes of toffee and caramel are emitted by the pour. A deep mahogany body and a whipped tan head. A cornucopia, =  plums, dates, raisins, figs, vanilla, a fresh loaf of honey nut wheat bread. The palate is sensational! It‚Äôs so creamy and velvety! Some spices that I can‚Äôt identify? Light notes of chocolate, a touch of nutmeg and coriander, maybe lavender? This is a sensational use of malt‚Äôs! Yeasty, bring a slender bittersweet finish‚Ä¶‚Ä¶ What a great beer! I will certainly be aging a few bottles of this!Post Note: - Reminiscent notes of a fine Tawny Port, - Enjoyed this brew to the maximum!
Deep ruby color. Clean roasted malt aroma. Great malty sweet complexity. Malty finish makes this a wonderful sipping beer.

Bottle conditioned. Deep copper bronze, moderate thin white head and good condition. Sweet aromas of chocolate, malt and caramel with some oakiness noticable. Good barley wine notes in the mouth with toffee, caramel, silky chocolate and a slight fruitiness. Carbonation is a little over assertive. Finish is quite short and malty sweet.

Deep brown color with some orange and yellow hues showing through, something like light ancake syrup.  Head is medium thick and khaki color.  Smell is delicious, if only all beers could smell this delightful: brown sugar, dark & candied fruits, and a spicy hop bite. Taste isstong and interesting: grapes, raisins, prunes up front with sugar, heavy malt and slight hopping. Lucious aftertaste, coating and sweet. Strong beer. Sampled from a 12oz bottle purchased at Whole Foods in Vienna, VA.
Deep auburn brown colour. Malty and sweet throughout. Seems pretty well made, but just too sweet and sticky for me. Bottled, Antwerp, September 2003.

Bottle Conditioned. From BeersOfEurope. BBE Oct 2005.  Wood-spice aroma, a bit leathery, some alcohol fumes, oranges - very nice. Soft palate with a creamy texture that thins too quickly. A good fruity flavour with a decent whack of sweetness that never overwhelms. Enjoyable, but perhaps needs a bit of aging to develop more interesting flavours and character.
Malty as heck, thin, pretty sweet and alcoholic, but saved by some true woodsiness and pepper - otherwise a toffee malt heaven for some.

Bottled: Clear amber coloured. Huge beige head. Malt, spices, alcahol and light cocoa notes in the aroma. Very mild and smooth flavour. Very pleasant. Malts, fruit and some light roastyness and alcahol is present. Has a great alcaholbitterness in the end. Yummy.
Bottled. Clear nut brown, rich head. Mild coffee up front. Dry with fine elastic, firm maltiness. Notes of chocolate. Salty, woody finish. Simply beautiful.

This was a very drinkable and enjoyable Belgian Strong Ale that I would definitely recommend to those of you who enjoy this style of beer. It poured a large sized tan head that was very creamy and contained fine-small sized bubbles that lasted for most of the duration of my rating. The body was carbonated, cloudy and the hue was reddish-brown. The nose was malty, caramel notes as well as notes of alcohol at 8% ABV. The flavor consisted of alcohol and caramel and the palate was smooth and medium bodied. There was a fair amount of lacing with this beer.
caramel/malt smell; very dark brown with a thin tan head; very smooth; taste of caramel and alcohol, but the alcohol taste is not at all unpleasant as I've found in others

This brew poured a large head of fine to large sized foamy mostly lasting bubbles that left behind a transparent brown colored body with no visible carbonation and a fair lacing.  The aroma was a nice caramel malt one with raosted notes and the mouthfeel was very smooth and thick from start to its lingering malt finish.  The flavor is very nice with notes of strong sweet dark malt and well hidden alcohol.  Very scrumptious and well recommended!

A deep reddish brown ale witha beige head that dissapeared quickly.Strong sweet malty aroma with hints of prunes and figs.The malt is really impressive in this ale. Has a nice lively mouthfeel with a nice crispness. First flavor that stands out is cherries and malt. Doesn't seem as though the yeast is playing as big a part in this belgian compared to others I've had. This is a very flavorful easy to drink Belgian in my opinion.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Pours deep dark brown with ruby tinges. Beige head with good retention. Aroma of dark fruits (raisins, prunes), berries and chocolate. Very clean deep aroma. Medium-full mouthfeel, smooth finish. Lovely subtle taste of dark fruits (raisins and prunes once again!), chocolate and sweet caramel. Very well balanced, not bitter, but not too sweet. Very nice, and VERY drinkable. ABV is brilliantly masked. Top stuff!

deep garnet color with a tint of brown. head is dark beige and lasts. aroma is a little cherry and a lot musty with slight alcohol! quite a fruity flavor as well with a finish that is slightly metallic and chocolatey.

Looks and pours like mud but has a nice light brown head, very fruity(prunes?) and alcoholic nose, almost chocolatey flavour with the alcohol repeating on you then back to the prune juice, complex and medium texture. Drink this at the right temperature and it gets better.

Deep, murky reddish brown with somewhat rocky, creamy tan head - mostly diminishing. Some lacing. Big banana aroma along with a butter and caramel. Hint of soap. Heavy alcohol and yeast in the flavor. Nutty. Mild hint of bitterness in the finish. Bananas Foster in a glass. I love this beer. An all time favorite.

Deep rich brown coloring, that has an interesting appearance just watching the pour meld into this deep beautiful auburn color,with a slightly creamy head.  On tap at Flying Pie, so it was very cold, so while I was eating, I let it sit for awhile and warm up.  The taste and mouthfeel to me was very much like prune juice, very full and complex and full bodied.  LOts of dark fruits, figs, dates, raisins and of course prunes.  Very sweet and easy to drink.

Mahogany auburn color, no head or lacing as expected (it was on tap, very cold). Cordimon and dark fruit aromas with caramel nuts & rye bread. Sweet easy drinking flavor, mild grapefruit (not hops), banana, vanilla, licorice. Palate has detectable alcohol and citrus notes. Overall this is an easy drinking BSA, not as harsh as the grand cru but that is the point I guess. It's like a silk blanket with a thread of wool every couple feet. Aged a little with a subtle sweetness.

Dark red-brown. Brownish head, slim but going down lacey. Raisins/(dark) sultana's, fruity, alcoholic nose. A rich X-mas cake. Taste is outspokenly sweet. Alcoholic, ridden with (fruity) esters and higher alcohols. Flavours of fresh figs, plums, pears, dried dates. Watered-down dark brandy (Armenian?). Less acidity than in the No√´l. As usual with G.C., the texture is thinnish and completely at odds with the OG/ABV. A bit soupy, after all. Liquid fruit cake. It remains a classic in every sense. I think the managment buy-out has been for the better. I'm not sure about the new names, though.
Dark Brown colored, cloudy.  Rich flavor of brown sugar, syruppy, a little molasses.  Very sweet.  Sweet finish, a fine brew.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2003 Reddish, dark copper colour.  Detected alcohol heat at the nose.  Rich caramel body gives way to some heat at the end.  An excellent beer; I would have rated it higher, but I found the pronouned alcohol somewhat distracting.

Brown colour. Nice head, doesn't stay long, though. Wonderful aroma, reminds of some creamy chocolate dessert I had once (can't remember it's name). The taste is a smooth mix of coffee and chocolate. The alcohol is there but stays in the background.

If you ever had to choose a beer to accompany a chocolate cake or creme caramel choose this. The chocolate malts and smooth creaminess in the nose are soft and silky with the contrasting creamy head a real treat. The first sip confirms this as the immediate mouthfeel is warm and chocolatey with the right touch of malt bitternenss. Hop presence is low but for this style right on the money. I vote for a category known as Belgian Porter.
user_location: Potts Point, New South Wales, AUSTRALIA

text: Wonderful caramel flavor and mouthfilling, smooth flavor.  Alcohol evident, but deceiving.  Absolutely world class.

Dark and mysterious this beer is.  Thick,molasses and alcohol laden nose that is very similiar to Corsendonk Christmas Ale but a tad lighter.  This is very carbonated and reminds me of chocolate pudding  and english toffee.  Yeast is subdued....man, I swear there is a Hershey's Symphony bar somewhere is this.  Beautiful  belgian ale that is highly underrated on this site.

Malty, sweet, fruity aroma, with some brown sugar, banana, plum and raisin, also some faint bubblegum and spices.  Deep brownish red color, opaque, with a fine and intricately patterned head.  Flavor derives primarily from malt and yeast, with an overriding, vinous, estery fruitiness, dark sugar and faintly spicy hop.  Finish is long, tangy, bittersweet and gently alcoholic.  Enjoyable as a dessert or nightcap.

Rich red/brown is semi transparent and keeps up a nice head. Malt and bread aroma reminds me of Old Peculier. However, this is much more fuller in flavor, fruity and sweet and hints of chocolate. One of my faves that got me hooked into strong Belgians.
Nasty candy Sugar Daddy flavor.  Horrible.  Sweet sewage, at best.  Never again.

Deep Ruby hue with a big foamy head. Sweet malty nose, rich fruit...plums, currants mixed with the scent of leaf litter on the forest floor. Earthy and yeasty with spice undertones. Sweetness dominates, almost a stickiness on the lips, rich and warming. Nice mouthfeel. I'm sure I will enjoy this even more when I try it in a cooler climate, not sitting here sweating in the tropics.
Looks darker than I expected.  More complex than I expected, too.  Caramel, toffee and hints of fruit.  Would be nice to have an aged bottle to try.
Raisen alcohol aroma.  Deep caramel color.  Too much of an alcohol flavor.  Very sweet.
Bottle, 8,5% ABV. Diminishing light brown head. Red-brown colour. Full and smooth body, slightly flat. Malty aroma with raisins and chocolate. Sweet taste with notes of chocolate. Very nice.

The aroma is slightly sweet, malty, fruity, and with notes of berries. The color is a beutiful deep red with a beutiful though fast disappearing head. The flavor is a little sweet from a good malt blend - a pretty complex flavor. An OK beer without being fantastic.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2004 Re-Rate: Drinking now at 14 degrees celcius in the proper glass and I am very very impressed. Aroma is cherries and brandy (noticeable alcohol). Appearance beautiful dark red, quite clear with a small slightly offwhite head. Flavours are smooth brandy, malt and cherries. Quite thick without being syrupy. Drank side by side one bottle labelled Gouden Carolus Carolus D'or as described above (same as the pic) and one labelled Gouden Carolus Classic (no foil). The "Classic" version was 8.5% rather than 8%, was lighter in colour, sweeter and lacked the cherry aromas and flavour.
Grape and port wine aroma.  Little head.  Prune juice in color. Flavor is grape and dark fruit.  Sweet up front with dry finish.  Very wine like.
Sweet, yeasty ale. I was not too impressed with this one. Also noticed some bitterness, but overall too sweet.
Caramel coffee nose. Well balanced and on the dry side. Nice finish. Lower carbonation level than most belgians.
Draught. Dark brown colour with huge head. Nice aroma of caramel, coffee, dark fruits etc. The same stuff in the flavour. Some anise notes as well. A great brew.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2004 Draught. This is a great brew. Strong toffee, choccolate and coffee notes. Definite strong choccolate aroma. The beer remains however still refreshing. That¬ís absolutely amazing. "Sk√•l" to Het Anker!!

This one pours a hazy, dark brown color with a mostly diminishing, small off-white head. The aroma is strongly fruity with hints of banana, caramel, yeast, vanilla, and brown sugar. Full body with moderate carbonation, it has a slightly syrupy texture and flavors of sweet, dark fruits, sugar, toffee, and yeast. The finish is long and sweet with a touch of caramel and vanilla. An excellent beer that leaves you licking your lips and wanting more.

Very, very wine-like in flavor, texture, aroma...but not the carbonation.  Highly carbonated with big, robust bubbles.  Very yeasty aroma.  A touch of sweetness balances this beer out, and it's not too bad.

Nice compact head on an inviting copper/amber body.  Aroma of alcohol, raisins and sugars.  Flavor is subtle (perhaps even "subdued") but complex.  Vinous initially, then many flavors push their way through - apples, grapes, raisins - then come heavier, maltier flavors, with caramel and maybe even brown sugar.  Warm, medium bodied.  A nice little belgian indeed.
very iffy belgain.  it was a very middle of the road beer.  i guess i had too many good beers and i lost track of the wood through the trees...

Cloudy brown liquid with a bubbly head on top.  Red licorice dominates the nose with malt coming in a close second.  Alcohol and a apricot fruitiness also in the nose.  The body is malty and has a surprising and nice bitterness.  Ends somewhat fruity.  Nice complex ale.
Yummie raisons and slightly alcohol nose. Cloudy murky brown color, no head, soft -nearly flat carbonation. Nice Yeast malt, caramel and pineapple taste- what a mixture. Ligth but fullmouth. Great.
High aromatic aroma, no surprise that alcohol was there as well with some sweetness. Mixture of sweet with Belgian yeast. Not best combination. Just pretty average sample of Belgian Strong Ale.
This is a good ale. Has fruity, caramel, and roasty flavor.  Finishes malty, creamy and bittersweet.

Raising, syrupy nose with a touch of alcohol; ruddy-brown color and a low tight head. Heavy sweet malt body with tastes of brown sugar and a slightly spiced end. Full body and a thick syrupy texture. Good after dinner beer.
Rich dark brown w/ lots of sediment & big beige head. Fresh bread & bubble gum nose. Chewy. Flavour is complex: dough, fruit, caramel, toffee, nuts.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2007 Dark amber color, cloudy. Sweet and malty with lots of licorice. Some roasted malt and hints of milk chocolate. Pear and pineapple. Served very cold, but I detected a fine maltaroma that becomes more prominent as the beer warmens. A warming sensation of alcohol. Well balanced beer!
Gouden Carolus 1984, tasted in september 07 in De Kulminator Antwerpen. porto aroma, somewhat dusty. Sweet sugary flavor with a hint of cherry and porto. Even a hint of chocolate. Cherry sweets in the aftertaste. Still in top shape after 13 years. (7 4 9 3 15 = 3.8)
Nothing wrong with this beer. Looks very nice and warm. Smells like fruit (grapefruit, banana, raisins?). Tastes warm and sweet. I really liked the combination with some chocolate.
Dark beer with a constant slick of a head.  Aniseed aroma and flavour with hints of malty coffeeness.  An intriguing beer with highly complex elements, and a very good drink.

The dark caramel color looked fabulous in the official Gouden Carolus glasses.  The head was healthy and entertaining (I like to watch it settle).  The aroma was subtle and pleasing to the nose.  The assault on the tongue was slow, and the caramel and oak flavors eventually subsided to the spike of the carbonation that lingered on the tongue afterwards.  About half way through the glass, there was a noticable oily feel left on the roof of the mouth and tongue.  I imagine that was what caused the flavor to linger like it did.
Aroma is of toffee. Has a deep brown body with some beige head and mega particles. Creamy caramel taste that doesn't cover all of the alcohol. Minimal bitterness. A solid Belgian Strong.

a welcome and ruby-orange denizen of the snifter, like a liquid cedar mulch, with proud tresses of oatmeal colored lace.  lightly hazy with a ghost of micro fine yeast. aggressively arromatic nose pretends to be buttery bananas flambe¬¥ in the half second before the flames consume the fog of alcohol.  sizzling sugars and hazelnut apple puree¬¥, a scent for sore noses. perfect carbonation and a cider sweetness are caressed to an elegant finish by the sculpting hands of skilled bitterness.  thicker body and longer finish would nudge it to the brink of greatness.

Looks great. Really big body and nice off-white head. Unusual (for this style) banana aroma but otherwise nice caramelly malts. Flavour reminded me of a ¬ímini-me¬í version of Rochefort 10. Not as much going on but quite similar. A touch of alcohol on the palate but sweet maltiness a just enough hops are enough to make this a good brew.
Sweet, malt beer
Deep brown with large tan head. Tiny bead. Rich malt nose. Sweet choc malt flavor.

Beautiful appearance, well described by ¬íjbrus¬í (see his rating). Lovely sweetish aroma with toffee, dark fruits (plum?), and alcohol. Flavour is initially sweet and fruity/malty followed by a long, malty, and soothingly bitter finish. Definately a wonderful beer!

On the pour, the beer appears to be a somewhat caliginous cherry red color, the head Bunyanesque in size, the texture creamy, with sticky sheets of lace to caress the glass. Nose is fruit sweet, over ripe apples and or banana comes to mind, malt tones and light caramel hints also present a treat for the old honker to sniff. The start is honey sweet, the top lean, the finish is pleasantly acidic, cheerfully hopped, dry and somewhat alcohol bitter aftertaste. Yes, it does ¬ìWarm the Tummy¬î, and should definitely be put in the ¬ìWinter Warmer¬î category. If you like strong high ABV beer this is a must try, but you may find it a bit pricey at $10.49 a 750ml bottle. Personally I don¬ít mind the price, because ¬ìI¬ím Worth It Baby¬î! Ranks #279 on my current 1000 beer master list.

Pretty, light brown.  Nose, full of caramel.  Flavor carries over the caramel notes and adds in lots of chewy fruits, plums, figs, the whole "ripe, dark fruit" standard boilerplate language here.  Alcohol is a bit overly noticeable at the end, but still very enjoyable as a brew.

loved the color, opaque burnt caramel. a lot of alcohol in the nose. lacey thin head which clung to the sides of the glass after each sip. very thin bodied.

the first sip, i thought "mmm, tasty" -- this was right out of the fridge/cold. i then had to make dinner and let the glass sit for a while, the alcohol nose got even stronger and so did the vinous sweetness. it didn¬ít taste much like beer at all. sour cherries mixed with sweet candy apples. unfortunately for me, not really my favorite tastes in a beer.
Long time ago, but I remember this to be a good beer, very full of taste
This is some good stuff!  Dark brown, plummy, figgy, "purple" tasting stuff, smells great, tastes great, I should have bought the big bottle!
Wow now this is a nice dark stong Belgian ale.  Chocolate, raisin, banana, plum and vanilla notes.  Taste is impressive as well, just the right amount of sweetness thrown in.  Very tasty.

Flowery, malty, fruity, sporty and racey. Oh babe.

AC/DC rulz. I was forced to type that.

Beer was good and so is the music!

Dark brown body and medium head. Aroma is quite sweet, probably too much so. WAY too sugary...the malt is candy/caramel flavored and was overwhelming. I had difficulty getting the whole 750 down. Spicy and fairly well balanced but the sweetness was too much for me.
Dark brown with a small head. Sweet malty aroma and taste. Nice full taste.
Chocalate, grape flavor, sugary but tart,  towards the end the grapy wine flavor comes through more and more.
Subtle warmth from the alcohol, nice complex taste like raisins, easter chocolate. Palate not to thick. Very, very fine ale.  Similar in impression to Rochfort 10
Nice flavors... spice, aroma, good color and a nice after taste.

Hazy dark brown body that pours with a quickly dissipating head.  Rich fruity aroma that¬ís all over the place -- I smell raisins, cherries,  banana and vanilla.  Sweet flavor, a bit yeasty and spicy, with alcohol undertones.

Okay, this is the first Belgian that I¬ím rating from a real chalice, rather than my old straight-walled pint glass, so the visuals might be skewed. Not a whole ton of tan head, dark ruby body, malty nose. Thick mouthfeel, much thicker than the flavor - I do have some allergies acting up, which may be affecting my perception, but I didn¬ít have problems tasting the Chimay Blue I had before this one. Hmmm. Fruity, with a touch of spice. Got better after I had a piece of Chimay cheese.

Deeo amber color.  Very Flowery aroma that is quite undescribable.  The taste was lightly sweet and extremely refreshing.  A little bit of grapes, a little bit of semisweet chocolate.  But still refreshing with a mild pop in the center of the mouth.

Very good aroma, my first taste impression was a little metallic, but when you dink it you get overwhelmed with a very massive taste, alcohol is something on the background. Palate stays in your mouth for days... (when you have patience) Great beer.

#420... My new favorite beer, ordered on the spur of the moment after the waitress told me they were out of Nocturnum. On tap, deep brownish with a grape colored hue. Light head with lacing. Most amazing flavors i have had in a Belgian, with perfectly sweet grapes, plums, and banana at first, changing abruptly to tones of chocolate and cherry before ending in a sweet , yet lightly drying finish. The taste lingered long after i took a sip. As of now this stands as my new #1 until I can get my hands on my old favorite World Wide stout.

Faint hazy deep deep amber brown with super fine bubbled, large, lasting tan head generating drift wood lace.  Fresh caramel malt, bubblegum, banana and a light cookie dough yeast aroma. Rich velvety smooth festive beer  palate. Medium soft body, alcohol well masked with big classy balanced yeast and caramel flavours. Light bitter and sweeter fruity malty kick off, soft sweet malty halftime and final. Stands up nicely alongside its bigger brother.
Dark brown with a small vanishing head, fruity aroma, sweet spicey and fruity with a nice finish. Very pleasant.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 Brown rum flamb√© over wealthy meat, raisins and roasted malts¬ÖA good sherry with dark chocolate, perfectly blended and intelligently sweet...Subdued torch lighting in an elegantly rustic castle hallway¬ÖHet Anker truly have no reason to envy the Rocheforts of this world, their malt control is absolutely stunning and delectable...

Special beer.  It has a taste of Rochefort, Guinness, but is not as rich like those.  I was a bit dissapointed about the ¬íkraag¬í (How do you say that in english???)  Anyway, great colour.  Don¬ít drink it too cold.
nice commercial beer, dubbeltype, nice presentation, behaves well on tap, easy going for the customers i have, but nothing special in the aftertaste than caramel, could do with some more spice

Starts off with a huge aroma of feral alcohol that blows your head off. Initially nasty as flavour couldn¬ít get past the aroma. Soon turns to toffee and banana elements as it warms. Spicy finish, not really smooth. Nice deep colour, floaties, little head. Interesting, worth another try.
Dark amber color with a rich head.  Flavors of toffee, orange and passion fruit.  Finishes tart with a cedary spicy character.

Medium dark color, very little head despite being adequately carbonated, you can smell the alcohol (8%) in the aroma, otherwise pretty drinkable, better than many other Belgians that don¬ít hide their alcohol as well.  Hard to find, sadly, so I won¬ít be rerating it any time soon.
This is a good belgian brown ale....very strong aroma which was somewhat displeasing but it tasted good.
Sweet and rich, just the way I like it!  Wow, I¬ím surprised the average for this wonderful beer is as low as it is.  Flabbergasted, I tell ya!

Had this from tap again and somehow it¬ís ok and somehow it¬ís not. Especially the look. It¬ís hazy brown looks like rust and still it¬ís clear against the light. Strange. Nice creamy off-white head and good lacing. Bit vanilla in the aroma. Sweet, soft, some spices, little licorice in the finish.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2009 Bottle. Head is initially large, frothy, light brown, mostly lasting. Body is hazy dark orange-brown, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately to heavily malty (caramel, molasses, toasted bread, roasted grain/nuts), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of plum, raisin, Bit-O-Honey candy, brown sugar, orange zest. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety/watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly to moderately alcoholic. Solid and reliable, but never quite jaw-dropping. A bit too sweet, but overall quite enjoyable.

Aroma is of toffee. Has a deep brown body with some beige head and mega particles. Creamy caramel taste with some alcohol. No bitterness in this at all. The yeast break-up really spoilt the appearance and experience of a good tasting beer. Did I get a bad bottle? No bitterness, not even a little?
Smells like brown sugar, deep burgandy colour.Toffey, caramel taste, gets richer as you finish. Complex and delicious.
UPDATED: JUN 11, 2004 I am a big fan of the Belgian beers.  This one is good, but not the best I have had.
UPDATED: JUN 2, 2009 Brown coloured, nice lasting head. Complex aroma and flavour, malts, raisins, molasses, vanila and dried fruit, quite sweet. Very nice Belgian strong ale.

750 ml:  Nice aroma of raisins, rum, and spice?  A bit thin in body detracted from this beer.  Somewhat of an acidic twang and decent warmth of alcohol.  Similar to a Raisin D¬í Etre, however that was much better than this.  An above average Belgian Barleywine.  Should age gracefully for many years so I will have to re-rate again.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Dark amber ale. Malt aroma, spicy, fruity. Sweet, strong malt flavour; this brew still needs some aging. The palate is equilibrate.
Has a ¬íwell-aged¬í aroma and flavor. Complex nose.
Red brown coloured. Malty aroma. Full taste. Two thumbs up!

#300!!! Tried this because the bar didn¬ít have the Flemish sour ale I had requested. Was pleasantly surprised to find a nice copper colored brew with a fine lace of bubbles lining the glass. Slightly dry and mild with a hearty malty/alcohol taste. Wonderful, fruity taste that only improves as it warms.

Dark amber/copper, exuding a pleasant melon aroma.  Melon, apple, banana (and some alcohol) are primary flavors of this extremely tasty, smooth, and delicious brew. Pleasantly sweet, but not overly so, this unheard of has become an instant favorite.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2004 excellent stew of roast, dark chocolate, prunes, caramel, fat sweet malt, coriander, astringent spice. some hot alcohol. should cellar magnificently, at the moment it¬ís a bit raw and scattered.
Nice autumn color with nice apple tones, although a little sweet and the palate is a bit short, strong yeast flavor that detracts
This is a nice beer. Liked the fruit notes and its somewhat chewy mouthfeel.  The malty taste is there, but not overbearing.
pleasantly sweet. a little heavy in the mouth

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2003 dark ruby-brown colour, big creamy head, nice lacing, malty, prune aroma, bready, vinous, very smoot, lightly sweet, sharp bitterness with a touch of acidity, long dry malty finish with notes of alcohol - robust and complex, the freshness of the mouthfeel is tempered by the quite heavy finish
not a fan, but it wasn¬ít that bad, not too rich and bit of toffee? caramel?

Some starting berry aromas fade to persistent banana notes. Some candy flavors but herbal and carmel flavors are more dominant in it¬ís medium-low effervescent body. It finishes with some soft alcohol spice.  Very nice.

a very malty yeasty ale.
a little too strong for me.

From the 1st sip I fell in love with this beer, the aroma reminded me of banana¬ís as well as the flavor, very aromatic and nice bubbles, though some might not like this, I found it to be pleasant and relaxing.
Rich, dark Belgian ale.  Strong dark fruit notes, and probably too much yeast for my tastes.
